Almost certainly, no breeding populations of southern crested grebes remain in the north, although New Zealand's two other grebe species are found there: the New Zealand dabchick and the Australasian little grebe. Ibid. 83 New Zealand's only endemic species of grebe, the New Zealand dabchick or weweia.., a small and threatened species found in the North Island, shows the same peculiar structure possessed by all grebes: webbing is absent and the toes are expanded into broad lobes.

Pureora's endangerd dactylanthus population has a rare claim to fame - it is one of the few sites where another endangered endemic species, the short tailed bat, is known to assist with pollination of the plant. .. Dactylanthus is New Zealand's only completely parasitic plant and grows at several sites in Pureora Forest Park.

Author: BAKER
Quote:
... in constant use

In the rural
districts [of New
Zealand] a
formidable body of
idiomatic uses is
developing and a new
language is being
coined. This isno
more true than it is
of the `remote'
back-country of
Canterbury, where
changing vocabulary
is already a
noticable
geographical
characteristic. The
local idiom is
naturally often
linked with sheep,
wool, and station
practice. `Dag', for
example, is a word
used first to
describe a tuft of
wool fouled by
excrement. The
removal of dags from
the hind-quarters of
sheep is a seasonal
operation usually
called `crutching.'
Used personally,
`dag' was earlier a
term of some
approbation. Its
meaning has widened,
however, and now
signifies no more
than `hard case', or
`tough guy', or
`card.'

He was a tough old
dag, and no mistake.

`Herringbone' dairies, developed in New Zealand, are increasing rapidly in number. Ibid./ 83 The backing gate is used to bring cows from the yard into the dairy. Its main purpose is to keep stock near the milking area. As each cow is taken in to be milked, another fills up the space it has left and there are no delays in milking. The gate is controlled by the milker, who can bring in the next cows without having to leave those already being milked.

Author: HILGENDORF

Quote: Wherever the South African Osteospermum (locally called `golden daisy') has taken root ... it has engaged in battle with Ulex, gorse.

The unusual animals
- a kind of circular
starfish - store
food in their feet,
have no stomach and
live in a soup of
bacteria in the
holes of wood lying
1000 metres under
the sea ... Dr Baker
said last night he
proposed to call the
class sea daisies -
after their
daisy-like shape.
... The sea
discovery is the
highlight of a
marine ecosystem ...
which museum
scientists here
recently found.

Author: WILSON
Quote: Celmisia MOUNTAIN DAISIES Celmisia is a large genus of daisies with about 60 species in this country and the remaining few in Tasmania and Australia.

Author: DAWSON
Quote: [caption] Two mountain daisies are present, C[elmisia] semicordata below and C. armstrongii above. Ibid. 179 Mountain daisies or celmisias are probably the most frequently encountered of our alpine herbs. a. Celmisia coriacea, =cotton plant.

ibid. 210 ... the great Mountain Daisies [fn Celmisias of various species, notably Cel. coriacea.] and other plants which fleck the upland meadows with purest whites and softest yellows ... [Celmisia coriacea] The great white buttercup of the Southern Alps, handsomest of its genus, grows in profusion, only rivalled in beauty by the marguerite-like flowers of the numerous different kinds of `cotton plant' or mountain daisy [fn Species of Celmisia.]. To this assemblage of plants also belong the New Zealand `Edelweiss' [fn Helichrysum grandiceps.] (no mean representative of the Swiss plant [190] from which it derives its name), and the exquisite white-flowered ourisias [fn Ourisia macrocarpa and macrophylla.], ...

Author: COWAN
Quote: Most abundant are the giant alpine buttercup (Ranunculus Lyalli), popularly called `mountain lily', and the celmisia or mountain daisy, called by the Maoris ti-kumu.

Author: MARRINER
Quote: (And)

As adjective, often used as part of the name of a species found in the back country, mostly smaller than their down-country relatives, e.g. m. pine, totara, minnow, duck (blue duck), daisy, lily (Mount Cook lily). (C.)

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote: Celmisia coriacea (The Mountain Daisy) ... Both Islands, mountainous districts. The Mountain Daisy. ... There are many varieties. Ibid./ 449 Most of the [Celmisia] species are found in sub-alpine regions, and are termed by the inhabitants Mountain Daisies or Cotton Plants.

... the
brusquely-interrupted
tea and the race
over the paddock
next to the `Daisy
Patch' with one or
two of us dropping
in the machine-gun
fire.

Author: SHADBOLT
Quote:
There [on 5 May 1915
in the front line]
survivors were
ordered to cross an
exposed strip of
ground, frosted with
spring daisies,
before [the
Turk-held hill] Achi
Baba - a place long
to be cursed as `The
daisy patch'. ...
The daisies were
soon less
conspicuous than the
blackening blood of
dead and dying New
Zealanders as more
and more were urged
across the open
ground. ... After
the daisy patch,
demoralisation and
anger was as rampant
among New Zealand
officers as among
men.

Author: WAITE
Quote:
"You're not going to
charge across the
daisy patch, are
you?" "Of course we
are," the
Aucklanders replied.

Author: PUGSLEY
Quote:
Every battalion had
its "Daisy Patch".

They went first over
broken country,
butafter a time came
to a level
plateaucovered with
wild flowers. This
was "TheDaisy
Patch". There the
men began tofall.
(And) Senecio Kirkii

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Daisy-trees. Olearia, various sp.

The native fuchsia ... and the fierce bush-nettle are conspicuous amongst the undergrowth, ... but we see but few species of the characteristic New Zealand daisy-trees [fn Species of Olearia.] Ibid. 188 Still higher we enter the sub-alpine scrub, ... Here the vegetation, though dense, assumes a dwarf and stunted appearance, and consists largely of shrubby veronicas, white and yellow-flowered daisy trees [fn Olearia and Senecio.]

daisy-cutter and the
transport driver
done his block and
took his hook.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote:
Daisy-cutter. 4. A
German shell that,
on impact, burst
instantaneously and
scattered its
fragments very close
to the ground: New
Zealanders': in G.W.
Cf. grass-cutter,

... a

bursting low.
Notes: McNab NZ Slang Press[Slang of the NZE.F.]

Quote:
Bunglebah must be a
daisy-cutter if the
time.. cabled over
to the daily papers
for the Epsom
Handicap.. is
correct.

On the porhc dak
curls away in a grey
green highway / from
Aotearoa to a nation
on the spur of
Africa.

The women are
passing a joint
around - "dak" they
call it these days.

If you want a
cruisy, clear day,
smoke some really
good, locally grown
dak.

NZ First MP Ron Mark
remains Parliament's
most vociferous
opponent of
decriminalisation,
convinced that such
move would see
Parliament go to
"dak and ruin".

Grow a bit of dak
for the readies.

[Hdg] Dak and ruin
amid mass
inhalations.... New
Zealand First's Ron
Mark suggested that,
since the Government
was happy to back
compulsory testing
of police and
defence personnel,
it should set an
example by
introducing
compulsory
drug-testing of MPs
and staff. "Or are
we to allow
Parliament to go to
dak and ruin", he
added., mystifying
more innocent
members with his pun
on one of the many
cool slang names for
marijuana.

So, when Ron Mark MP
suggested drug
testing our elected
representatives in
the wake of the
latest
joint-spotted-in-House
brouhaha - memorably
punning a threat of
things going "to dak
and ruin" in the
process - it was
unclear to an
irony-challenged
individual like
myself whether he
was serious.

So, when Ron Mark MP
suggested drug
testing our elected
representatives in
the wake of the
latest
joint-spotted-in-House
brouhaha - memorably
punning a threat of
things going "to dak
and ruin" in the
process - it was
unclear to an
irony-challenged
individual like
myself whether he
was serious.

The bigger or more
skilful boys won
mostof my marbles
off me, their
glassies orsteelies
(ball-bearings)
blasting my
claydakers
ruthlessly out of
the ring... The
result was an
ominous jungle, to
be viewed through
the peephole for a
daker a time.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
daker marble;
variant of
Australian `dakes',
marbles.

Author: STEWART
Quote:
Marbles.. was played
with those beautiful
and beautifully
named taws such as
agaties, cat's-eyes
and glassies
(glassies were to be
found in the tops of
lemonade bottles)
and with the small
clay cannon-fodder
called dakes. You
knocked your
opponent's dakes out
of the ring with
your taw, and then
you could keep them.

Author: PARK
Quote:
With red faces and
eyes bulging with an
afternoon of
stooping, they fired
their taws, green
and blue and
brilliant yellow, at
the squares richly
lined with the
weatherbeaten old
clay soldiers which
sold at twelve a
penny and were known
as dakes.

The dakkies of old
were the sort of
thing you could pull
on over a pair of
big thick socks to
watch Sunday night
television, not
caring if you spoilt
kebab sauce on your
lap or Ribena down
your front.

You just knew,
likewise, there'd
never be a moment
when Wacko and
Debbie would rip
their daks off at
the same time and in
the same place.

Source: Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success
Quote:
When she realised I
wasn't putting my
daks back on she
turned her attention
to Paul.

Author: McGEE
Quote:
And dogs, madam,
dings dallies
dutchies dagoes
boongs chinks gooks
wogs commies
coconuts coons
kaffirs pommies
polys woollys gollys
spics spucs spastics
the PYM queers and
other long-haired
fairies - yes! We
love them all!

There was a time when our word was our bond, when you would help your fellow Dally. Why? Because he was Nash... When we visited our relative or friend in hospital we brought them good Dalmatian food, after all, who of the Dallies had a stomach for plain English food? [49] W e all knew who was a Dally - by their faces, real Slavonic and broad, with high cheekbones - by their special walk or gait which went with their breed.

Author: SARGESON
Quote:
One of the two young
Dallies who ran an
orchard up at the
back of Mrs Crump's
place. ... had come
out from Dalmatia.

The father's a
Dally, but the
mother is Irish, as
far as I know.

Author: SHADBOLT
Quote:
You fullows guess I
am bloody Dally from
Dalmatia, eh?

Author: FINLAYSON
Quote:
Dally: Dalmatian,
Yugo-slav.

Author: LELAND
Quote:
New Zealanders whose
forebears came from
Dalmatia in what is
now Yugoslavia. The
Dallies are
concentrated in the
North of the North
Island and tend to
be farmers and
winemakers.

Author: ROSIER-JONES
Quote:
Emma stiffens at the
word `hori', but
surely he's not
referring to . .
.[sic] `Emma has got
Dally in in her
y'know, Fred,' the
manager says.
`Coulda fooled me.
Looks like the old
tar-brush t'me.'

We all roared at
Billy T. James'
Irish joke. Could we
have more please -
about coconuts,
dallies, poms and
horis? Chows too, if
possible.

Dally NZ colloq. 1
a. of Dalmatian
origin. 2 n.
Dalmatian immigrant.
[abbr.]
Notes: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 120]

Author: JOHNSON
Quote:
'The Dallies don't
need a compass,'
they'd say. 'All
they need is to be
able to recognise
Rangitoto. They
never go out of
sight of it.'

And there was "a
Dally from
Dargaville" with a
brand-new Commodore
who wasn't that keen
on being towed by it
[sc. 1 1928
Chevrolet truck].

Author: SARGESON
Quote:
He was young, tall,
strong, handsome,
with cut of features
besides dark eyes
and colouring which
suggested Croat
descent [43] what an
earlier generation
of New Zealanders
would have called
Austrian before the
latter-day settling
for Dally or
Dalmatian.

On local wine's
academy awards
night, cpomplete
with statuettes
known as "Dallies"
for the biggest
winners, the
inevitable
controversy over who
won and who didn't
is normally accepted
as an inherent
feature of the
festivities.

Source: Te Araroa: the New Zealand Trail
Author: CHAPPLE
Quote:
'The Dallies made
them,' said one of
the workmen, 'way
back in the 1930s.'

Northlanders were
gumdiggers, Maori
and 'Dallies', and
none of these
epithets was a
compliment.

Author: SARGESON
Quote: Two young dallies who ran an orchard ... had come out from Dalmatia. Ibid. 00 Apples do best on land like that, so it was apple-trees the Dallies had mainly gone in for.
There was a time when the orchards and vineyards of Henderson and Oratia were ours, when Lincoln Rd was commonly known as Dally Alley.

Then there was their
treatment of the
Croatian migrants
who arrived at the
turn of the last
century to dig gum
in the Far North.
Being not quite
white enough, they
were called, among
other things, white
Chinamen and Dally
dogs.

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
Broke off his
engagement ... and
got this dog off an
old Dally
scrub-cutter.

Author: GEE
Quote:
`She knows I like my
vino,' he explained.
`Where did you get
it, Corrie? Is it
dally stuff?'
`Henderson special,'
... `Not dally
though. ...'

Author: PHILLIPS
Quote:
Dally Day is a
stayers day, a test
of endurance not
just for horses and
riders but for the
pounters as well.
The Dallies arrive
before the first
race and are still
there after the
10th.
Notes: Martin Tolich "Dally Day" from Metro Arpil 1966

Quote:
I was.. planning to
take off on my big
OE, maybe even check
out the homeland,
see where those
tough old Dallie
winemakers had come
from...

Author: IRELAND
Quote:
wishing to catch
poems he could salt
/ and peg out on a
line in the wind /
to dry like a Dally
fish

There was social
card-playing and
Dally bowls with a
round bowl - not
off-centre - and
grape wines, and
dances like the
kolo, done in a
circle.

'The Dallies don't
need a compass,'
they'd say. 'All
they need is to be
able to recognise
Rangitoto. They
never go out of
sight of it.' While
there may have been
a small amount of
truth in the jibe in
the 1930s, when the
'Dally fleet' was
inclined to be the
butt of jokes by
other members of the
fishing community,
it was not the case
in the 1940s.

Tim's [Shadbolt]
Team sank the Dally
mafia without trace
in yesterday's local
body election. Mayor
Tim recorded a
massive 30,488
votes, compared with
nearest rival Tony
Covic, whopolled a
paltry 7481.

Our society, which
represents a very
large percentage of
Yugoslav Dalmatians,
is concerned that
any paper can
slander our
community by calling
them Dally mafia ...

Author: STEAD
Quote:
In Mike's childhood
New Zealand was
still a
beer-and-whisky
cutlrue, and the
local wine was
popularly known as
Dally plonk.

You can buy an awful
lot of Dally plonk
for four pounds.

Author: SHADBOLT
Quote:
And I make Dally
plonk, all right. My
plonk here is not
best, soil too sour,
but is all right.

Author: WATSON
Quote:
On Sunday we ... had
a barbeque on the
beach with the fowls
and a bottle of
cheap Dally plonk.

Author: BAXTER
Quote:
I do recall one
evening, drunk/ In
Devonport on Dally
plonk,

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote:
Dally - Dalmatian,
made by Yugoslav
immigrants; e.g.
`Dally plonk' -
Dalmatian wine

Author: McGILL
Quote:
Dallie plonk the
often rough and
usually red wine
sold here
mid-century, when
most Kiwis were beer
drinkers, before the
Dalmatians got their
wine act together
and Kiwis atarted
drinking the grape,
c.1960s.

Author: RENNIE
Quote:
His only experience
of wine was the
rough, home-made red
Northlanders called
`Dally plonk'. see
cits at Dally

Source: Avondale College Slang Words in Use
Quote: (Dally) plonk

We told everyone
that we were
Dalmatians and later
Yugoslavs and we all
stated this with
pride - after all,
this respect had
been earned with
much sweat and just
as many tears, in
the gold fields of
the South, on the
wild gum fields of
the North and in the
mountains of
Coromandel and in
the swamps and
drains of the
Hauraki Plains.
There was a time
when the distinction
in our community,
between a Yugoslav
and a Dalmatian was
alomost impossible
to discern.

Author: GEE
Quote:
I chose vineyards
where the Dalmatians
didn't use shotguns.

Author: SCOTT
Quote:
Coates: We have
difficulty in the
north in connection
with the Dalmatians.
Notes: 1916 Gordon Coates speech in 1987 Scott Seven Lives on Salt River 148

Quote:
Twelve people at
work [in Waikato].
English French Swiss
Dalmatian.

Author: HYDE
Quote:
Sweat rolled down
the Dalmatian's
matted chest.
Martinovitch came
from the gum fields,
and worked as if God
were in him.

Author: HYDE
Quote:
Then one little
Chinese moved close
. . .[sic] not that
he'd have spoken to
her, it was the
Dalmatian quarter
[of Auckland] where
all the thick voices
said whiningly:
`Good night girlie'
...

Author: CRESSWELL
Quote:
The evening before,
a kindly Dalmatian
had cut up a sheep's
carcase for me ...

Author: HAMILTON
Quote:
A Dalmatian once
told a friend of
mine why he left
Europe.

Author: BOSWELL
Quote:
Besides the
[gum-]diggers, more
especially the
Austrians - or
Dalmatians as they
later insisted on
being called - paid
well for the
service; ...

Author: GOLDBLATT
Quote:
... an excursion to
the vineyards that
the swarthy
Dalmatian stock have
sown ... and brought
to fruition in the
ways of their
forebears on the
hilly slopes that
carry the tang of
the Adriatic Sea.

Author: REED
Quote:
Towards the close of
the nineteenth
century some
Yugoslavs, or
Dalmatians,
discovered that, by
hard work, good
wages could be made
on the gumfields.

Author: BOOTH
Quote:
... compounded on
the Dalmation[sic]
coast before he
migrated ... the
dialect of his
Dalmation[sic]
village birthplace
...

Author: SHADBOLT
Quote:
[Dalmation] `There
were gumfields all
around here, weren't
there?' `That's
right. Crawling with
Dalmations. Only
they were called
Austrians then. ...'

Author: McLAGLAN
Quote:
...the [kauri gum]
industry was largely
in the hands of the
Dalmatians who came
to dig and remained
to settle as
excellent colonists.

Author: THOMAS
Quote:
... the Austrians
soon established
themselves as fine,
hard-working and
law-abiding people.
... When the map of
Europe was changed
after the First
World War they
changed with it and
became known as
Dalmatians.

Author: ANDERSON
Quote:
... I remember two
[stories] about
Maoris and one about
a Yugoslav or [45]
Dalmatian, as they
were then termed,
told by a foreman
who had come from a
North Island job.

Author: SARGESON
Quote:
He was young, tall,
strong, handsome,
with cut of features
besides dark eyes
and colouring which
suggested Croat
descent [43] what an
earlier generation
of New Zealanders
would have called
Austrian before the
latter-day settling
for Dally or
Dalmatian.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote:
Actually Joe, the
Dalmatian
proprietor, who
hardly remembers his
real name himself
anymore, never
leaves his home and
business entirely
unattended even
during national
emergencies.

Our society, which
represents a very
large percentage of
Yugoslav Dalmatians,
is concerned that
any paper can
slander our
community by calling
them Dally mafia ...

Author: BATISTICH
Quote:
Austrian was our
first name here and
it stuck. But it
wasn't the name of a
country the New
Zealanders invoked
when they said it;
it was the name of a
fear. ... With every
shipload
ofDalmatians coming
to work on the
gumfields that fear
grew. ... But to my
child's mind it was
all a confussion -
all those names.
Austrian. Dalmatian.
Some said Croatian.
And now Yugoslavs.

Author: BATISTICH
Quote:
For ours was a
two-way world, and
I'm still not sure
what I am, New
Zealander or
Dalmatian first. But
I know this, the
scent of the
tea-tree will always
say Home to me,
calling me back to
dusty North Auckland
roads.

Author: SARGESON
Quote:
Nick was saying he
was a New Zealander,
but he knew he
wasn't a New
Zealander. And he
knew he wasn't a
Dalmatian any more.

Author: BATISTICH
Quote:
No use for Mr
Mitchell to boast
that he'd been one
of our marchers in
Auckland's Queen
Street that day in
1914; the Dalmatians
had carried an
Austrian flag all
right, lifted it
high and burnt it
for [24] all of New
Zealand to know what
we thought of being
called Austrian.

Her pride and joy is
the Dalmatian bean.
She says just about
everyone in the
north grows this
bean, which has been
here for at least
100 years... It is a
tall-growing runner
bean.

The country
lifestyle reflected
in many of the
stories has gone
now, and the
characters - the
swaggers and hawkers
and Dalmatian
gumdiggers and stern
Presvbyterian
fathers - have gone
with it.

Author: BAKER
Quote:
Late in the 1800s a
lot of Dalmatian men
left Europe, looking
for a new life away
from chronic
unpleasantness in
the Balkans.

Author: SHADBOLT
Quote:
When we declined
their beer they
triumphantly
produced some sherry
from a Dalmatian
vine-yard ...

Author: KEINZLY
Quote:
The little Dalmatian
manager had
sauntered up through
the tables.

Author: BAXTER
Quote:
The Jar [title] ...
I'd bought a peter
of wine/ From the
owner of a Dalmatian
vineyard,/

Author: SARGESON
Quote:
Why? I said, there
are plenty of
Dalmatian girls out
there. I bet you
could get plenty of
New Zealand girls
too.

It's easy to get
lost in the lush
dalo fields of
Muaniweni, a farming
settlement.. about
an hour out of Suva.

dam n. an embankment
for restraining the
flow of water; the
water so collected.

A question on the
Evans Bay dam in
which a six-year-old
boy was drowned ...
was raised ... at a
meeting of the
Wellington City
Council last night.

The Waingongoro
River near Hawera is
home to the
successful
dam-dropping and
white water sledging
adventure.

Hawera has its own
high adventure treat
for tourists in the
form of "dam
dropping" on the
swift Waingongoro
River. I politely
declined this
white-water sledging
invitation... Fact
is, I didn't much
like the thought of
leaping off a dam
six metres high.

Author: GRADY
Quote:
Dam - Mother whale
in lactose state,
with calf in
company.

By the early 1900s
dama were believed
to be extinct on the
Australian mainland,
but DNA tests proved
that the dama that
Governor Grey
released on Kawau in
1870 were originally
taken from South
Australia, and
therefore a pure
strain of the lost
species. Kawau dama
(Aussies say
"tammar") are now an
international star
for forensic
genetics, but it
won't save them.

The Aussies heard of
the 2005 eradication
target and
immediately ordered
30 dama wallabies
from Kawau.

Author: McALPINE
Quote:
I tried to cook for
weeks on that
wretched thing till
I found out the
damper had cracked
and fallen into the
soot at the bottom.

Source: Hints to Intending Sheep-Farmers in New Zealand
Author: WELD
Quote:
As occasion might
offer, he should not
think it a
degradation,
gentleman born
though he might be,
to heap fresh logs
on the fire, put on
the soup pot, or to
bake a damper in the
ashes.

Author: CHAPMAN
Quote:
What the host always
furnishes is tea (at
every meal), damper,
i.e. a sort of dough
cake baked in the
ashes, very good if
well made and fried
pork.
Notes: Quoted in Miller; Early Victorian NZ, p. 140

Quote:
Bread in the shape
of a very palatable
kind of damper, or
unleavened cake, is
now an essential
part of native food.

Shew that the
constant use of
"damper" amongst
colonial shepherds
(being a perpetual
feast of unleavened
bread) renders them
just as likely to be
the lost tribe of
Israel as the
Maoris.

Author: GRACE
Quote:
As they sat and ate
their simple fare -
"damper" baked on
the red-hot embers
of their fire..
their conversation
was of their
"claim".

Author: ORBELL
Quote:
DAMPER. This
requires the same
scone mix.

Author: HOCHSTETTER
Quote:
`Damper' is a dough
made from
wheat-flour and
water without yeast,
which is simply
pressed flat, and
baked in the ashes;
according to
civilized notions,
rather hard of
digestion ...

I'd flood it and
have boats and cook
damper and do a sort
of Huck Finn thing.

Good damper keeps
for a couple of days
and makes excellent
toast.

And this, too, to
colonials who had
known most of them
what it was to
hunger and thirst
after "damper" or
"johnnycake"
warranted to stay by
a man for three days
at a stretch! - to
long vehemently for
Maori hen only three
removes from a
watertight boot
soaked in hair oil!
- who knew most of
them what it had
been to partake of
'"Sunday duff "
boiled in a kerosine
tin.

Author: SEWELL
Quote:
That is what is
called fat damper,
otherwise scones, a
Bushman's delicacy.

Author: PAUL
Quote:
.. night after night
on the damp cold
ground, mutton,
damper and tea ...

Author: MONEY
Quote:
These and other
employments, such as
baking my dampers
...

Author: MARTIN
Quote:
Boundary-keepers'
food consisted of
the ubiquitous
damper, boiled and
fried mutton and
tea.

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Quote:
And weka, uncared
for in the
settlements! Catch
it, as Mrs Glass
would say, at
Rotoiti or Cape
Foulwind; stuff it
with sage and onion
(for even these
condiments accompany
the epicurean
explorer), roast it
on a stick, watch it
for half an hour at
daybreak, spattering
and hissing between
you and the fire as
you make the damper
or pancake, while
your companions are
snoring under their
blankets around you,
and then serve it
upon the saucepan
lid.

Being regularly
knocked up, I meant
camping for the
night, so I laid
down, and took a
feed of his damper,
mutton, tea and
sugar.

Mr. Colenso having
shown so much
sympathy with the
sufferings of the
clerk of the roads,
might expend,
without appearing in
the least
ostentatious a
little of that same
milk of human
kindness with which
he is so completely
saturated, upon the
unfortunate pork and
damper fed
surveyors.

Author: AYLING

As their name suggests the adults of both sexes are a uniform black in colour with a prominent white ear spot that can be turned [239] off and on like a signal light ...

DAMSELFISHES 1543-5

retropinna, or

These are sometimes caught in large quantities by whitebaiters. The fishermen call them `Dan Doolin Spawn' or `Whalefeed'.

Author: BAKER

By the 1890's the

pleasure.

Author: SOLJAK

New Zealand
colloquialisms which
are of Maori origin

haka: to celebrate

Dance a haka. To

Zealand coll.: since

The haka is a Maori
ceremonial dance,
wild and impressive.
Cf. the Australian
corroboree, n. and
v.

A hundred and one
pubs and
danceshanties, and
them fine girls
shakinga leg with
the diggers and all
goingstrong till
daylight.

tango, to dance the:
of a sheep, to
struggle whilst
being shorn.

Dancing Cossacks
1975; because up
until then election
campaigns had been

Quote:
... [The storm
petrel] has many

Dolly, frigate
petrel - from the

takahikaremoana from

Big Brother has also contributed to the national lexicon with the wonderful term "dancing doonas" (the furtive activities going on in the bedroom of the Big Brother house).

The joys of helping
Dad to deliver the
milk.. with the

dandy, were shared

children.

Many of the original
"Danskers" have sold
out.

Author: LEVY
Quote:
Many an aspersion is
cast at a danthonia
knoll waving white
with rank growth,
and the grass is
condemned as being
unpalatable, whereas
the person casting
the aspersion is
probably standing on
the very same grass
eaten down so well
that it is to him
`English grass'. ...
the better English
grasses are seldom
seen to much
advantage when
growing within a
danthonia or a
browntop sward. I
consider the
stunted, ill-natured
herbage of the
better English
grasses is less
palatablethan the
young, fresh herbage
of the second rate
species.

Author: DUGGAN
Quote:
She sat faced out to
the paddock of dry
danthonia grass,

Author: MARTIN
Quote: Soils of poor quality both upland and lowland are commonly known as Danthonia country, by which is inferred their poor quality.

Author: LEVY
Quote: With the onset of autumn rains, the bared ground, which was clothed originally by the once-dominant danthonia turf, is replaced by annuals. Ibid. 88 [Table 1] Danthonia tussock

The property when
taken over consisted
of 28 acres of sandy
gumland hills in
weak browntop and
danthonia pasture,
reverting back to
manuka.

Author: DAVIS
Quote:
We climbed the
boundary fence and
our hobnails bit
into the
smooth-stalked
danthonia grass of
the lower slopes of
the Kitchener Flat.

This flag is
neglected by sheep;
they prefer the
shorter green grass.
In danthonia
country, therefore,
as in rough bush
country, it is
profitable to run a
limited number of
cattle ...

.. if we are going
to dilly-dally
around with one ewe
or less to the acre
on danthonia
country, we will
never get a good
sward.

Snow-grass, carpet
grass, hassock
grass.
danthonia A large class of Australian and New Zealand grasses of which one is valued as a pasture grass; the largest is the `snow-grass' of the New Zealand mountains.
danthonia n. tufted perennial NZ and Australian pasture-grass. [E. Danthoine, botanist]
Notes: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 121]

Quote: Danthonia semi-annularis, a variable grass found in nearly all soils and situations throughout the colony.

... coarse
tussock-grasses.
(Danthonia)
a native grass, strictly Danthonia semiannularis

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote:
This must not lead
the farmer to
suppose that
`danthonia', as all
these different
forms are called in
the papers and by
seed-merchants, will
ever replace
ryegrass, cocksfoot,
or red-clover in the
better land.

Author: PERRY
Quote: During the past few years the use of danthonia, the best of the native grasses, has considerably increased. Danthonia pilosa is the best type, ...

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: DANTHONIA (Danthonia semiannularis and D.pilosa) [(Notadanthonia spp. syn. Danthonia sp.)] is a native grass, of more than one species, often occurring as a weed in permanent pastures in dry country.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
On hard hill-tops
and narrow ridges
and knobs, danthonia
and microloena had
grouped themselves
in little companies.
... the land becoming gradually less productive owing to the replacement of good by poor pasture plants such as redtop (Agrostis), Danthonia and Chewings fescue.

Author: LEVY
Quote: Of the grass associations, danthonia may be regarded as an indigenous induced association and browntop an exotic induced one; ... Ibid. Appendix II 354 Danthonia - Notodanthonia spp.

Author: FAIRBURN
Quote:
In time of drought/
The danthonia shines
like a flame.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
There were the
scrublands of
blackened second
growth, the pastures
of danthonia and
browntop ... the
marginal land of
bracken, hebe and
flax, the
reproachful columns
of burnt-over bush
...
danthonia [s] [12 Notodanthonia sp(p)]

Author: TAYLOR
Quote: DANTHONIA (Rytidosperma sp(p)). ... Some species are native but several were probably introduced from Australia with early shipments of sheep.

Author: WHEELER
Quote:
Unless you walk over
this country
[Central Otago]
you'll miss the
native grasses, like
danthonia and the
blue tussock. To a
Merino, one mouthful
of this hard feed
[13] is worth 10 of
soft greenfeed.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
I started a fire
when I could
scarcely walk, the
danthonia dry as a
county chairman's
speech.

On poor tussock
country .. the use
of danthonia
invariably increases
the
carrying-capacity.

.. the land carries
danthonia, mainly,
with manuka and
matagouri on the
lower levels.

The following
applications for
patents were
gazetted last week:-
.. an invention for
manufacturing
brushes and brooms
out of New Zealand
grass, named
danthonia raoulia,
more commonly known
as "snow grass," by
Henry James Shaw, of
Christchurch.

The herbage was
principally the
large coarse snow
grass (Danthonia
Raoulii); to this we
set fire in several
places, which
rapidly spread over
the rough hill side.

Some of the land is
is [sic] poor, but
danthonia is making
its useful way
through scrub and
fern.
The open mountain top is covered with a growth of grass, but it is of a very coarse character, being no other than the Danthonia Cunninghamii and Danthonia Raoulia, or snow grasses.

Author: LEVY
Quote:
One direct outcome,
however, of this
increased carrying
capacity was to
overcrowd the stock
camps on the knolls
and ridges and to
submit the former
danthonia-dominant
turf to such
intensity of wear by
treading,
scratching, and
rubbing, together
with rank
fertilising of the
camps by dung and
urine, ...

I've put some DAP on
my best paddocks
around the house.

Local advice on
recommended rates of
DAP should be
sought.

Author: MARTIN
Quote: Another very floriferous shrub to be seen on the [204] drier hillsides of Nelson and Marlborough and of North Island hills is known as the NATIVE DAPHNE or TARANGA (Pimelia longifolia ). [chk pimelia]

Author: HOLCROFT
Quote:
We returned from
North Canterbury
with a spread of
native daphne
donated from a
garden ... a few
miles from Rangiora.

Author: DUNCAN & DAVIES
Quote: ... (And) Pimelia longifolia

Quote: New Zealand Daphne - taranga, Pimelia longifolia

Author: WILSON
Quote: Pimelea lyallii SAND DAPHNE ... Low, sprawling sub-shrub ... Flowers white, strongly scented, attractively clustered at branchlet tips.

[Hdg] "The Darg"...
The darg is a means
used by coal miners
and men employed in
other occupations,
to provide work for
three men where the
employer would
require only two...
A similar system is
being adopted by the
Amalgamated Society
of Engineers.

Author: MILLER
Quote:
For a good many
years I have run a
daily column in the
Southland Daily News
called "The Day's
Darg," a mixture of
fact, comment, verse
and humour. "Darg"
is a coalmining term
meaning a norm of
work.Theoretically,
when you have
finished your darg,
you go home, but
somehow that has
never worked for me.

The perusal of
Hansard is not part
of my daily darg,
thanks be!

Author: FRAME
Quote:
And on my last day
in London, Ben, the
poet, paid me a

Michael Morris of Wellington, says the term "deal to" sounds strange to him as a New Zealand citizen returning after 22 years away. He says he hears New Zealanders but never British people saying "deal to" and much to his surprise has also seen it in print here. He quotes a Lloyd Jones short story saying "... and the intervening coastline looked to have been dealt to with a meat cleaver".... That said, "deal to is accepted by Oxford's Dictionary of NZ English with plenty of citation.

In shape, [the
family

usually long, deep,

compressed and
flattened on the

that their local
appellations always
embody some idea of
these peculiarities
- such as

and also oar-fish.

The Oar-fish, 12 to
20 feet long, with a
high, flame-tipped
head-crest (the
elongated fin rays)
is probably the
sea-serpent of
repute. Its pelvic
fins are narrow,
elongated processes,
hence the name
Oar-fish. The
Deal-fish is much
smaller, but of the
same type, but we
know very little of
the habits of either
of them.

Independence. This
[sc copy of treaty]
instrument I
consider to be de
facto the treaty,
and all signatures
that are
subsequently
obtained are merely

adherence to the
original document.

To calm the nervy, a

maa-maa.

three sheep placed
in it decoyed others

Berry, to decoy the

and tied it up.

yards where several

quietly feeding

On a morning of

of young cattle

Bay beach.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
The tip, a small pen
capable of holding
10 or 12 sheep, was
situated a foot or
so above and partly
overhanging the dip.
... with the aid of
a lever it could be
tipped and the sheep
sent slithering into
the dip below. The
decoy pen was so
situated that two or
three sheep placed
in itdecoyed others
onto the tip.

The decoy pen acts
as an inducement for
incoming sheep ...

With side-delivery
dips, often a decoy
pen is used - on far
side of dip.

Author: RIDDOLLS
Quote:
The tip platform
extends from the
sheep entry gate to
the decoy pen gate.
The tip platform
consists of three
parts - the frame,
the tipping portion
and the decoy pen.

Author: WHITWORTH
Quote:
These ... are
gentlemen who give
their talents and
time to the paternal
Government for a
certain modicium
[sic] of payment,
and are as known
D's. [check cit.
?D.s??]

I was informed that
the D's were hanging
around that
vicinity.

Wellington Detective
Department showed a
mean sort of spirit
over Detective
Sergeant Cassell's
farewell. As is well
known the popular
`demon' has been
transferred to
Napier, ... The
uniformed branch of
the police ...
wished him all sorts
of good wishes, but
the other branch,
the `Dees', was not
represented, ...

I asked a young man
what was the matter,
and got the reply,
`Oh, it's nothing!
Only the d's pinchin
a little piece.' ...
I found that d's
were detectives ...

and not letting that
bloody dee bulldoze
me.

The bloody Ds told

bloody lucky she
didn't get clink.

those dees are,'

Quote:

was beaten up by the
cops/ For telling a
dee his house was
not in order.

Sittin' there,

Once a dee, always

Author: BARKER
Quote:
We were well
mounted, and all our
luggage consisted of
my little
travelling-bag ...
and what is termed a
`swag' in front of
F--'s saddle; that
is, a long narrow
bundle, in this
instance enclosed in
a neat waterproof
case, and fastened
with two straps to
the `D's,' which are
the steel loops let
in in four places to
all colonial
saddles, for the
purpose of carrying
blankets, &c.; they
derive their name
apparently from
their resemblance to
the letter.

Dee (d&emacr.), n.
[Written also D.] A
steel loop attached
to a saddle, for
suspending packages;
- so called from its
shape, which
resembles the letter
D.

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
He rolled his
Erewhonian dress and
small toilet
necessaries inside a
warm red blanket,
andstrapped the roll
on to the front part
of his saddle. On to
other D's, with
which his saddle was
amply provided, he
strapped his
Erewhonian boots, a
tin pannikin, and a
billy that would
hold about a quart.

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote:
When not in use,
whips were carried
coiled up and
fastened to the back
`D' on the off side
of the saddle by a
short strap that
could be quickly
undone when
required.

dee, D. n. D-shaped
metal loop or clip
on a saddle.

Author: R. GILBERD
Quote:
A `ropey' will learn
to snipe - which is
a highly-skilled
operation. The butt
end of a
clean-trimmed log is
trimmed of angles.
V's are cut at
points opposite each
other at the butt
end (usually) and
are connected by a
Dee which runs round
in a D from one to
the other. In the
Dee is laid a
`strop', a short
length of cable with
an eye in each end.
The eyes are
connected with each
other and to a short
chain by a shackle;
and the chain is
attached to `the
rope' with a hitch.

DEE: A groove in the
front end of a log
into which a strop
is fitted for
hauling.

Author: MOORE
Quote:
[The log] was hauled
by wire rope or
chain bridle. This
was attached
sometimes by cutting
a `D' in the top
half of the nose of
the log, or more
often by two heavy
spiked `dogs' which
were driven in each
side of the log ...

Ngai Tahu were
granted statutory
acknowledgement over
the lagoon as part
of their Deed of
Settlement.

Ngai Tahu were
granted statutory
acknowledgement over
the lagoon as part

Settlement.

The land transfer
system contrasted
with the older deeds
system, introduced
in 1841 as a
reformed version of
traditional English
real property law
whereby rights to
ownership depended
on the existence and
validity of a chain
of documents. The
term title deeds
derives from this.

habitually uses

Author: DUGGAN
Quote:
Obol and diobol, the
two in the one like
a symbol of

For the shilling bob
was the most common
nickname in use, but
also recorded is
deener. This latter
name was used more
widely in New
Zealand and
Australia than in
Britain. The
sixpence attracted
many slang terms -
tizzy, tanner,
sprat, bender, and a
kick.

Author: MACKENZIE
Quote: deener a penny

Author: MAY
Quote:
DEEP SINKING:
putting down a shaft
to tap a deep lead.
No absolute figure
can be given but
`deep ground'
usually required
shafts of over sixty
feet.

Large quantities of
gold have been
extracted from the
ground at the rear
of the township, and
it is well known
that several rich
leads of gold run
into the deep ground
which the lessees
are unable to work
with the limited
capital and
appliances at their
command.

Intelligent miners
inform me that it
would be an
exception to get
gold in this river
drift, or on the
reef underlying,
also that it is an
exception to get
gold in the deep
ground on the Arrow
river.

To miners who are
working deep ground
this is not of so
much consequence, as
they can stack their
dirt, if it is worth
it, until an
opportunity of
washing it occurs.

This society was
formed expressly to
test the existence
of gold in the deep
ground, and their
success has,
therefore, a
significance far
greater than the
mere value of what
they themselves may
obtain.

It has been an
unusually fine
winter, which gave
the miners a good
chance of working
the deep ground, and
the majority of the
claims have paid
well.

But controversy over
Eder's account of
New Zealand soldiers
killing Vietcong
prisoners while on
deep jay (jungle)
patrol has sharpened
public awareness for
his book.

The "Deep Jay" in
soldiers'
parlancemeans out in
the jungle.

Author: PFAFF
Quote:
We had a claim ...
over the terrace on
a deep lead.

... the alluvial
miners thought they
were dealing with
superficial alluvial
deposits; ... Deeper
workings showed that
the beds dipped
steeply, and the
gold continued
downwards, the
conglomerates were
then called `deep
leads', probably in
the belief that they
resembled the deep
leads of Victoria.

Author: EVANS
Quote:
This dredge received
its name from the

McGeorge Brothers
prospected for and

lead' or layer of
gold-bearing wash
deeper down and
separated from
thelayer that other
dredges in the area
had worked upon.

The downfolded

gravels and
alluvium, or
`younger drifts' of
the miners.

Thinkers'.

Excellent deer

water.

ck and fitness...

Author: STRONACH
Quote:
We called it deer
shooting, not
stalking, and we
were right. Stories
of the difficulty of
getting deer leave
me cold. Stalking -
trying to get a good
head or one
particular stag -
may be difficult,
but shooting deer
when they are fairly
numerous, as they
are on many
stations, is child's
play.

In recent years
there seems to have
been a tendency to
use both track and
trail and to
differentiate
between them. A
trail seems to be
something narrow and
perhaps rather
hardto follow - a
way marked only by
blazes or worn by
animals, usually
deer. A track seems
to be something
broader, cut or
formed by man. ... A
well-known older
Club member made
this distinction
when, on hearing him
speak of a deer
trail, I asked him
what he thought to
be the difference
between track and
trail. I remarked
that I thought it a
very recent
distinction, one not
occurring in the
Club until about
1957. He disagreed,
believing it to be
one he had always
known. Yet, on
looking through The
Tramper, I could not
find deer trail used
until 1944, but deer
track occurs from
the first number in
1928 onwards, and he
himself had used it

Source: Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand
Quote: When the selection [of the N.Z. Company share of the Otago Block] had been made the Crowngrant was to be issued, and there was an understanding that if Colonel Wakefield desired stillmore land he was to have it. This was the origin of what was afterwards known as thedepasturage licences, under which settlers were authorised to run cattle and sheep in the adjoining districts. Ibid. 138-139 Under the original terms, land purchasers were entitled upon payment of an annual license fee of 10s. 6d. to depasture or run sheep and cattle upon such waste lands within the block as remained unappropriated. ... though Captain Cargill was then gazetted Commissioner of Crown Lands for the Otago block only, he received no definite instructions upon the subject of granting the runs. [139] The result was that he merely filed the applications for depasturage licenses as they were presented to him, whilst the applicants were left to pursue their further course as seemed best to them.

Source: Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand

An old native, from

CLATHRUS CIBARIUS, THE `BIRD-CAGE FUNGUS'. ... It is found commonly throughout New Zealand during the late autumn and early spring. [Distribution.- Australia; Chile; ... New Zealand]

Austral. sl. (also
dickin, dickon) come
off it! cut it out!
[foll.]

Author: McGILL
Quote:
dicken disgust or
disbelief or
surprised belief, in
form of an
interjection,
largely replaced by
`really!' or
`really?'; an
antipodean
contraction of `the
dickens' or `what
the dickens!', being
a euphemism for the
devil. - dicken on
that! go easy, will
you!; eg `You want
me to help you lift
that dirty big post?
Dicken on that,
mate.'

'... It has not been
restrained by any
fear of the
penalties that are
provided for the
offence known as
'contempt', but by a
desire to assist in
preserving the
dignity of the court
and in upholding its
authority.' Dicken!

[Caption] "Say Kiwi,
some coot told meyou
were a wingless
bird." "Dicken
Yank,yer gotter have
arms when there's a
waron."

Author: DAVIN
Quote:
Dicken on that for a
joke.

The accused [,
Harman,] said:
`Murder ... dicken
on that, me murder
anyone.'

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
`What in hell are ya
doin in Christchurch
anyway? Bludgin on
the [check] social
security, I spose?'
`No. Dicken on
that.'

Author: McGILL
Quote:
- dicken on that! go
easy, will you!; eg
`You want me to help
you lift that dirty
big post? Dicken on
that, mate.'

Quote:
`... I thought your
husband looked a bit

me.' `Why would I
ask you?'

Quote:
dickey stupid; eg
'Well, I don't think
Billy T's dickey at
all, I think he's
neat.' [Alison Gray]

dicky rice weevil n
[prob. fr. the
nickname Dicky] : a
weevil (Malenterpes

and other fruit
trees

The new product is

"It's named after

friend and mentor."

Head Word: didn't come down in the last shower
Author: McGILL
Quote:
I didn't come down
in the last shower I
am not a fool; to
which the reply is:
`You mightn't have
come down in the
last shower, but
you're pretty wet
all the same.' NZA
variant of Royal
Navy's `I didn't
come down in the
last bucket.'

Head Word: didn't come down in the last shower
Author: McGILL
Quote: shower , phr. I didn't come down in the last shower claim to be not gullible, but shrewder than given credit for. NZA.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
she didn't leave a
fucking oat horse
racing c/p for a
filly the day after
winning a race,
indicating how well
she came through it.

In 2004 didymo was
discovered in New
Zealand, the first
time it was found in
the southern
hemisphere. To
restrict its spread,
the whole of the
South Island of New
Zealand was declared
a controlled area in
December 2005.

[advert] We need you
to knock the snot
out of Didymo.
Didymo is an
invasive Northern
Hemisphere algae
that threatens many
of New Zealand's
rivers.

The biosecurity
crises of didymo and
seasquirt are an
abrupt reminder that
all our activities
are conducted within
the context of a
natural world that
has no innate repect
for our interests.

Biosecurity's
allocation has
fallen by $21
million to $151
million, due to
spending in the year
2005-06 year being
lifted by "one-off'
funding for all
responses to disease
- namely fall
webworm, painted
apple moth, didymo,
sea squuirt and the
southern saltmarsh
mosquito.

Author: PERRY
Quote: They [sc. Southdown sheep] die well, i.e., have a small percentage of offal, and the bonesbeing small there is little waste. Ibid. The Ryeland kills well, and produces meat of a fairly good quality, ...

Author: MARSHALL
Quote:
I'm certain that big
die-offs occur in
harsh winters.

Author: PETER
Quote:
Died in the hole:
shearing term: not
quite reaching your
expected tally.i.e.
99, 199, 299. One
short.

Author: BULLER
Quote:
`Dieffenbach's Rail.
. . . This beautiful
Rail was brought
from the Chatham
Islands by Dr.
Dieffenbach in 1842,
and named by Mr.
Gray in compliment
to this enterprising
naturalist. The
adult specimen in
the British Museum,
from which my
description was
taken, is unique,
and seems likely to
remain so.'

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote:
The forest is
enlivened by
numerous tuis or
mocking-birds; a
little green
parroquet flocks in
hundreds to the
potato-fields ...
The mako-mako, the
finest songster in
New Zealand, is also
found here, being
another species of
the honey-eater. The
large New Zealand
pigeon, called
`kukupa', finds
plentiful food here
... A new kind of
rail was formerly
very common; ...
Notes: 1840 Dieffenbach An Account of the Chatham Islands Journal of the Royal Geographical Society 11 pp195-215 in 1984 Holmes Chatham Islands 95

Author: BULLER
Quote: RALLUS DIEFFENBACHII. (DIEFFENBACH'S RAIL.) ... Native name. Moeriki. ... [180] This beautiful Rail was brought from the Chatham Islands by Dr. Dieffenbach in 1842 ... [1888 edn, 2/12, places this specimen in Hutton's Cabalus modestus as Hutton's Rail.]

Author: FALLA et al.
Quote: Note: Dieffenbach's Rail (Rallus dieffenbachi), once abundant in the Chathams Islands, was similar to the Banded Rail in so many respects that that it may be regarded as a strong sub-species of philippensis. The last specimen was obtained in 1840.

Source: Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ
Quote: 131.b. Rallus philippensis dieffenbachii Gray, 1843 Dieffenbach's Rail Chatham Island, extinct (one specimen, 1840).

The second wave [of
extinction] occurred
gradually over
centuries as the
native crow, owlet
nightjar, giant coot
and Dieffenbach's
rail were lost.

There used to be
much more of the
push element around
Christchurch than
there is now, and it
frequently occurred
that pushes [i.e.
youths belonging to
these groups] like
the `Tigers,'
the`Diehards,' the
`Scalpers,' and the
`Skull-Draggers,'
faced the music
before the beak.

Author: WAITE
Quote:
By 4.30 a.m. on
December 19 [1915],
the last beetle
cleared from the
shore leaving the
`Diehards' of the
Division, only 3,000
strong, to hold the
line against a
mighty army. ...
[286] The `last
ditchers' were to be
sacrificed for the
army. There was no
lack of volunteers.
... men of Anzac and
Suvla alike - vied
with each other in
an endeavour to
become included in
the `Diehards'.
[288] Previous
parties had taken
the `Diehards' kits
and impedimenta.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
Dog tucker and
mutton on a place
that size will add
up to 300 or more
sheep and this
number pretty well
accounted for all
the old 'diers' -
sheep that would not
have seen another
winter out.

a sick sheep: a
dier. a sick cow: a
dier.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
This number pretty
well accounted for
all the old "diers"
- sheep that would
not have seen
another winter out.

Right, we're
dieselising tonight.
Notes: Wellington Bus Controller to bus driver, p.c. David Norton

Quote:
diet n.-The Diet n.
sl. England.

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote:
In affectionate
terms we discussed
the innards ... - of
their `carbies' and
their `diffies' and
their `con-rods'.

DIFM is the oposite
of DIY. Short for Do
it for Me...

I would not go and
dig for any man
under [pounds]3 per
day. It is killing
work.
Notes: 1861 Aug 14 letter from Tuapeka in 1867 Hochstetter NZ 110fn

Quote:
Kia Ora [pounds]
5000 Art Union./ Dig
down for that
half-crown right
now. Be in on the
last 5000 [pounds]
Art Union without
fail.

[Hdg] Astle's dig
among the game's
greatest.

Be shrewd, sweet
Dig, and let those
whowill die working.

How frequently a
'dig-in' could have
been avoided .. if
the tines had been
correctly aligned.
After a 'dig-in' the
points should be
always kept within
at least 1 in. of
their true line.

Prisoners [in the
Terrace Gaol,
Wellington]
frequently complain
that if the chief
gaoler gets a snout
on them they go into
the dig-out on the
slightest
provocation.

Author: NEWBOLD
Quote:
With the key in our
possession it became
possible to supply
any friend of ours
who was in the
digger with as much
tobacco, matches,
food, and other
delights as he
wanted.

Seven days in the
Digger on number two
diet... They let you
have a choice from a
selection of books,
most of them
insulting
nursery-rhyme stuff
deliberately chosen
by Mr Stone, the
unhappy screw on day
duty in charge of
the Digger.

Author: FOOTE
Quote:
Rangipo Prison
layout was the usual
rectangular plan,
two sets of cells
facing each other
across a central
grassed area with
one special cell
called 'the digger'
or 'dummy' to
isolate a
troublesome inmate.

Who is better
equipped.. than
"Digger Dick,"
practical miner,
Empire builder, and
the very active
personality behind
"Seddon, New
Zealand?"

We.. pulled up to
announce our arrival
to a rather
officious-looking
officer who wasn't
very impressed by a
few Kiwi Diggers.

Some of the Mounted
Rifles who have
recently returned to
Christchurch are
objecting to being
called Diggers... It
appears that the
term was practically
unheard of in
Palestine and Egypt.

Author: SMITH
Quote:
And splendid with
medals and ribbons,/
Old Diggers - the
country's cream -
Boyd from the days
of the Crimea,/ And
some from the Boer
War,/

The common method of
addressing a New
Zealander is to call
him "digger," which,
from being an
abusive term, has
been readily and
universally adopted
and approved by the
Pig Islanders
themselves. We, the
N.Z.R.B., prefer to
be addressed as
"diggers" rather
than "dinks" which
was the original
mode of address.
Notes: From a letter by Rifleman C A Palmer of Wanganui (nb: date entered in NZDE database was 31/4/1918)

Quote:
"Digger" is now the
common form of
salutation between
privates. It applied
to the Maoris only
at one time. They do
a lot of pioneer
work, such as
digging trenches,
but as we all do
more or less navvy
work, the term is
universally used
among the New
Zealanders. Really
the meaning is
"Friend" now.
Notes: This is from a letter from an Auckland soldier;

Quote:
Tommies and overseas
Kangaroos andDiggers
enter into
conversation
withpeasants, which
turn often
intoconferences.

In the colloquial
parlance of
the"Digger," they
came a gentle
"gutzer".

A hundred and one
pubs and
danceshanties, and
them fine girls
shakinga leg with
the diggers and all
goingstrong till
daylight.

Source: Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland
Author: HAAST

Many of the diggers
and storekeepers

loaded waggons from
Otago..were now

their stores on with

I am happy to say

and mica diggers

These "specimens" as
they are called by
the diggers, show no
- or very little
sign of being
water-worn.

Author: DAVIES
Quote:
Dick Dickson had
been a good deal at
sea,but for a
"digger" was well
educated.

I saw a shepherd's
wife take her child
out of a cradle and
sell the latter to a

note.

These Irish Diggers
(they hated to be
called miners) made
the place as bad or
worse than
Donnybrook.

The knowledge that
he has
beenrecommended by

recognitionhas met

his"digger" cobbers.

Digging-ploughs are

The lea land should

... [digging plough]

The evening was very

which, held by the

apace.]

digger's weed [=] Californian stinkweed [s]

Weed (Navarettia

Californian Stinkweed, Diggers' Weed (Navarettia (Gilia) squarrosa) . Ibid. 2 It is sometimes erroneously called "Bathurst burr."

Author: COOPER
Quote:
It is called by some
digger-mania, by
others
digger-phobia. This
dire disease is
usually developed
about a month after
the victim has
commenced digging;
its symptoms are
very varied and
curious, and are
anything but
agreeable to those
who are
unfortunately
connected with the
poor afflicted one.
Other miscellaneous historical (obsolete) names from the early 20th century include.. Diggerland, coined in World War I.

"Diggerland"... Can
you see thewaving
tussock grass that
yellows in thesun,
To the soft blue
haze of thedistant
hills that quiver
into one?..
Notes: Title of the poem is "Diggerland". The word does not seem to be used anywhere else and not in the poem.

Another aspect of

These birds were
less of a permanent

Just a stone's throw

boys
as"Diggerville".

C. Ring found it

rock by the presence

Boulders, ...

Author: MONEY
Quote: ... at dinner we had the pleasure of the company ... of a publican from Nokomai, a digging township on the road we were going. Ibid. 197 Pinkerton and Lady came board. Pinkerton is a publican who has made a lot of money in the digging time and his lady or rather as he calls her `My old woman' has ringlets.
Notes: 1873 Jan 23 G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 146

Author: HARPER
Quote:
[The West Coast] has

Lyell is a

digging township ...

Quote:
... the gold ...
[was] so much of a

... I have
frequently [c1860s]

terms are

Author: FITTON
Quote:
The digging
population is not
now what it used to

... while her decks

of those other

700 and odd

pannikins and

Quote:
Howards Digging
Plough .. turns over

Digging-ploughs are

Quote: Thousands of people had already flocked to the diggings from Sydney. Ibid. 546 ... the diggins '

Quote:
The excitement
respecting the gold
`diggings' in

...

If there be one
point on which all
those who have

Quote:
Some very fine
samples of gold from

thequantity about
five ounces. -->1853
Rochfort Adventures
of a Surveyor 20

Quote: Never mind - the diggings will not always draw people away. In a short time the overflowings of disappointed diggers will bring Ships and labour back and the tide of Immigration will flow again. Ibid. 1/123 Many houses to let in consequence of some persons having gone to the diggings - others over the hill (as they call it) into the Plains.

... the annexed
tabular report of
the work at this
Gold-field since my
arrival. ...
wherever I and the
Messrs. Ring have
`prospected' on the
Kapanga ..., we have
found gold, and that
the greatest number
of flakes in the
prospecting dish,
appeared upon
washing some earth
yesterday at a bar
about half a mile
lower down the
stream ...; and
below all the
present diggings.
Notes: (Heaphy's Report) Kapanga River Diggings,/ Coromandel harbour,/ 4th November, 1852.

Author: EARP
Quote: ... emigration to New Zealand has given way to the mania for the Australian gold diggings. Ibid. 248 They have their `Long Tom' at the junction of a small tributary with the Kapenga, below all the other diggers. Neither of the men have ever been at any other diggings.

On the resumed
diggings, the
parties ... washed
[7 1/4oz of dust]
... the quantity set
forth, and are
continuing their
work with every
prospect of finding
eventually the
matrix Gold, which
the nuggets now
obtained indicate to
be in the vicinity
of the workings.

The gold seems a
little more
promising according
to reports. Bearded
losels wandermore
and more up and down
the beach [at
Nelson] - to and fro
the diggings.

The character of the
diggings is
improving; the yield
of gold is much
better.

... at the end of
three months (his
nose having got
exceedingly red in
the meantime and
smelling worse that
ever of bad
tobacco), he goes to
that refuge for the
destitute, the
Nelson diggings.

Author: MUELLER
Quote:
I ...am now at the
Manokaiou where the
diggins are.

Nothing but one loaf
of bread left, could
hardly get firewood
enough to boil one
billy full of tea.
Met some mourays who
told us of the new
digins.

Author: WALKER
Quote:
The diggings [at
Dunstan] extend 80
miles one way and
fifteen another. If
you want to boil a
pot you have to hunt
about for dead `Wild
Irishmen' a nasty
prickly little
shrub. The high
lands abounded with
`Spaniards' I
suppose from their
cut-throat
propensities. A kind
of very thick grass,
grows in a little
lump.

Author: NESFIELD
Quote:
We travelled to ...
the Grey, and back
to the Buller,
calling at
Charleston and
Waite's Pakihi's;
all familiar
diggings to any
west-coast digger,
and very rowdy
diggings too.

Author: A TRAMP
Quote:
Bullen ... owned a
clothing store in
the principal
`diggins' of the
day.

diggings: place
where gold is mined.

diggings ... A place
where gold-mining is
carried on. b. on
the diggings, the
idiom (rather than
in) within the
precincts of a
goldfield.

Author: MONEY
Quote:
... I slept for the
first time `on the
diggings;' and ... I
confess I would have
preferred a warm bed
... to the slab
table with which I
was compelled to
content myself,
every bunk and
bed-place being
preoccupied, ...

Author: THATCHER
Quote:
He'd a mart on the
diggings here, and
in addition,/ He did
a great deal selling
things on
commission.

Author: McLEAN
Quote:
Someone found a
`diggins' at the
Hutt.

The men were only

`diggings' there in

Author: SMYTH
Quote:
What the `diggings'
do you think you're

Author: McGILL
Quote: digglers eggs.

Any man who thinks
and reads beyond the
immediate
requirements of
getting a good job

`gormless',
`dilberry', etc.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote:
A dupe; an easy
victim: Australian,
esp. confidence
tricksters': since
the 1920s. In, e.g.
Baker, 1942. Perhaps
silly
billy>Billy>Billy?)>
Bill> by `rhyme',
dill; but prob. ex
daffydill,
illiterate for
daffodil ... (cf
pill @n with
similar, though
harsher,
connotation) perhaps
dialectal relation
to dull (OE dyle),
or perhaps a NZ
shortening from
dilly (aj) (though
the reverse may be
true, dilly (aj)
from dill @n; dill
is a more friendly
term than dool (aj
doolish) which is
applied in anger or
disgust with
somebody's
stupidity.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH

Some of the [slang]

shoot, going eyes
out, bullswool, go

... shivery dick,

... you're telling
I, got iton the

Wellington).

His Worship: `Was
the accused sober?'
Witness: `Well, he
looked muzzy.' His
Worship: `What do
you mean by that?'
Witness: `He looked
either drunk or a
shingle short.' His
Worship: `A what?'
Witness: `A screw
loose.' His Worship:

in his garret.' His
Worship: `Oh, speak

[sic] - dilly.'
Sergeant: `He says

Witness: `No, I
didn't. I said he
was either drunk or
ratty.'

Author: CUMBERLAND

The dimples usually
occupy individually

square yards.

Subcutaneous dimples

...

Author: CUMBERLAND
Quote:
Subcutaneous
dimpling appears to
be limited to land

of European
occupance, has been
ploughed at least
once. Under these
circumstances
dimpling replaces
sub-surface sheet
wash.

Author: CUMBERLAND

From Marlborough to

various stages.

Since rather more

Of course, people

flavour.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
Dingy wool - in
practice this kind
of wool is described
with a variety of
names. In New
Zealand the most
common names are
'dingy' .. There [in
Australia] the term
'dingy' is most
often used to
describe discolored
wool in general. The
following discussion
is confined to wool
bearing excessive
amounts of sand,
earth and dust and
for simplicity it is
called dingy wool.
It is the rule
rather than the
exception to find
very weak back wool
in dingy fleeces.

Dingy: Discoloration
due to condition and
dust.

Tidy cover

Next came the New
Zealand Rifle
Brigade from Mersa
Matruh, first the
2nd Battalion,
nicknamed the
`Square Dinks' (a
`square dinkum
bloke' being
idiomatic Australian
for a genuine
fellow) from the
distinctive black
patch on the upper
sleeve; later the
`Diamond Dinks', who
wore a diamond patch
and had been in
action with British
and Sikhs in the
defeat of the
Senussi on Christmas
Day. The alternative
name of the Rifle
Brigade, the E.L.O.
(the Earl of
Liverpool's Own) had
been quietly allowed
to lapse.

Triangle Dinks Third

Christchurch's much

Emma" and Henrys was

Author: THOMSON
Quote:
Sometimes even
Dinkums proved too

shortened to
"Dinks".

The common method of
addressing a New
Zealander is to call
him "digger," which,
from being an
abusive term, has

universally adopted
and approved by the
Pig Islanders
themselves. We, the
N.Z.R.B., prefer to
be addressed as
"diggers" rather
than "dinks" which
was the original
mode of address.
Notes: From a letter by Rifleman C A Palmer of Wanganui

We were talking with
the 'Dinks'

Originally there
were two canteens

camehere in

beenenlarged.

That Dink now gets
quite mad when
theboys taunt him
about a certain
pigskinH.E.

The Drill Hall
barely accommodated
100"dinks" from all

whoattended the

Author: ANON
Quote:
I have seen a number
of university men of
the Rifle Brigade,
generally known to
us as the Dinks - a
name they have
cheerfully accepted
and try to live up
to. [fn] The
newspapers urging
enlistment in 1915
declared that the
later men, joining
the forces with
motives of reasoned
patriotism, would be
more praiseworthy
than the `impetuous
spirits' of the Main
Body. Hence
thesardonic nickname
of `the Dinks' -
dinkum soldiers -
attached to the new
brigade.
Notes: 1916 March 11 Letter from Egypt in 1965 Malthus ANZAC 156

Author: INGRAM
Quote:
This evening the
C.O. ... imparted to
them the information
that the Divison
with the exception
of the Rifle Brigade
(`The Dinks') was
going back ...

Our Brigade (2nd)
and the Dinks were
to advance with the
Australians.

The Dinks were
laying cable in the
forward areas, ...

Quote:
Colloquially the

Battalions were

The New Zealand

hold a reunion in
Wellington ... (How
did they get their
name? The black
buttons, badges, and
blazes, and
theunusual drill of
the New Zealand
Rifle Brigade led to
their being dubbed
`the dinkum
soldiers.' Shortened
to `The Dinks' it
was accepted as an
honourable title.)

A reviewer of

France," quotes the
nicknames of the
successive drafts of

"The Tourists" came

to see what the
adventure was like.
The next shipment
were the "Dinkums",
the true men;
followed by the
"Super-Dinkums".
Then arrived the
"War Babies" and the
"Chocolate
Soldiers", and after
them the "Hard
Thinkers" who
thought very hard
before they came,
and last of all the
"Neutrals".

The "Dinkums" have

even comparable to

arrivals had to
stand on that
fateful day, April
25th, 1915.

Shipley is

four-hundred-gallon
tanks ...
Notes: in Cresswell (1949) Early New Zealand Families

It would be
decidedly a good
plan to dip both
ewes and lambs off

Author: SCOTT
Quote:
I think that the
most unpleasant part
of the job was
scrubbing the posts
and rails and gates
of the sheep yards
with 'dip' but it
had to be done to
stamp out the
disease [scab].

The best feature
about these dips,
however, is the
beneficial results
so noticeable in the
wool at shearing
time. Each of these
dips is ideal for
its own particular
purpose.

It is obvious that the different dips which are now available are all produced for a specific purpose. Ibid. Oct. 25 [It] should give protection against maggot fly for 2 to 3 months when used in plunge or shower dips.
The basic ingredient used in all poisonous dips is the powerful poison arsenic.Ibid. 199 Sheep should not be dumped into the dip head first.

The dip
manufacturers.. are
reluctant for trade
reasons to recommend
any definitive
number of sheep
after which the wash
should be discarded.

Please forward to
Waihoa Downs at your
earliest convenience
another five cases
of "Puritas Sheep
Dip."

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Quote:
There are many who
use a solution of
arsenic as a dip for
sheep, which has
undoubtedly the
recommendation of
economy of cost, and
I believe, when
judiciously applied,
to be quite as
efficacious as
tobacco, as far as
curing the scab
goes.

One single important

We have finished

By systematic dipping this particular disease [sc. scab] has been eradicated from New Zealand flocks.

Careless dipping is
a waste of money.
The early
pastoralists were
faced with the

ever-increasing
flocks in an

and so were
developed the swim
dips and draining
pens and other
arrangements with
which every sheep
farmer is now all

If you started

you'd soon be
without any men at

Control [sc. of green blowfly] is by dipping, spraying or jetting with organophosphates.

Fish and Game New Zealand backed up its "dirty dairying" campaign rhetoric yesterday with scientific research by soil and water experts that claims a firm link between intensive farming and waterway pollution... The institute's report says waterways are in poor condition mainly because of "dirty dairying" and are likely to get worse. Ibid. 12 Mr Polson claims (June 19) that Federated Farmers is doing something about "dirty dairying" and he lists a series of schemes.

Something has to be

dairying and our

lakes, and the lack

country with so much
grass, the terrible
impact of introduced
pests on our
forests.

The forced

small authorities
into the Far North
District Council in

varying interests.

The broad scheme of
the Bill is to set
up district councils
which will replace
existing borough and
county councils and
may take over the
functions of many ad
hoc bodies such as
catchment
boards..pest
destruction
councils, and so on.

Magistrates courts
were renamed
district courts and
their presiding
judges district
court judges in
1981, but the term
magistrate in New
Zealand denoted
stipendiary
magistrates rather
than justices of the
peace, who were and
are usually referred
to simply as
justices or JPs.
(District court has
itself a history.
Originally district
courts were
intermediate courts
created in 1858;
they were squeezed
out between the
Supreme Court (now
the High Court) and
the magistrates
courts and were
formally abolished
in 1925.) The latest
episode of this
serial is the
creation in 1998 of
community
magistrates to sit
in district courts
and exercise minor
criminal
jurisdiction.

Author: McGILL
Quote: skate phr. do a skate to disappear hurriedly; aka skate off; eg `Potts figured there was trouble brewing and did a skate.' c. 1925. - phr. go for a skate a fall, mistake, failure, blunder or dismissal; eg `If he doesn't shape up soon he'll go for a skate.' - skate over/around to avoid, move over or blur something disconcerting; eg `She's always skating around the question, never really answering directly.' NZA.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Block, doing the v. lounging in the fashionable promenade. In Melbourne, it is Collins Street, between Elizabeth and Swanston Streets. In Sydney, `The Block' is that portion of the city bounded by King, George, Hunter, and Pitt Streets. It is now really two blocks, but was all in one till the Government purchased the land for the present Post Office, and then opened a new street from George to Pitt Street. Since then the Government, having purchased more land, has made the street much wider, and it is now called Martin's Place. Ibid. 37 Block, on the (1) On the promenade above referred to.

Author: GILKISON
Quote:
In the 'seventies
and 'eighties many
fraudulent debtors,
embezzlers and rich
thieves escaped from
New Zealand before
arrest, by doing
what came to be
known as the
`Pacific Slope'.
Someone discovered
that the Sandwich
Islands, which were
then ruled by a
native queen, had no
extradition treaty
with New Zealand and
consequently rogues
who were much
`wanted' by the
police in this
country on reaching
Honolulu could laugh
at writs and law
proceedings.

Author: MULGAN
Quote:
`Poor old Tom! He's
never been the same
since his partner
did the Pacific
slope.'

Author: GORE
Quote:
He never returned.
Tetley had done what
in those days was
termed `The Pacific
Slope', and was last
heard of in South
America, that haven
for absconders and
those anxious to
shelve their
responsibilities.

The employes [sic]
at a certain
flaxmill in the
district (says the
"Manawatu Times")
awoke one morning to
find that their
overseer had "done
the Pacific slope"
with nearly GBP200
of their wages in
his pocket.

The Wanganui
Chronicle says: The
latest idea in
"sweeps" is what is
known as the
"Pacific Slope"
stakes. All the
names of the
prominent business
men are entered, and
the drawer of the
next person who
leaves his Wanganui
creditors and
crosses the Pacific,
scoops the pool. We
hear that the stakes
are large, so it may
be worth the while
of the holder of
them to do the
"slope" himself.

The early eighties

Our biggest

sex, then earmarked

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
In the simplest form
of Tip Cat the
players competed to
see who could hit
the cat farthest.
The cat was a thin,
six-inch stick with
pointed ends. Their
bat (or dog) was a
round stick about
the size of a
cricket wicket (two
and a half feet
long). The cat was
placed on the
ground, tapped on
its point, and then
as it jumped up into
the air, hit once
more.

There are about 150
ways that an
employee can earn
demerit marks, and
to escape them
hemust wear wings
and a halo, and be
capable of miracles.
So that a marked man
is easily got rid of
or disrated. One man
complained at the
meeting of the
manner in which he
had been `dogged'.

By the way, this
gentleman got a
severe hurt last
week through being
rushed by an excited
cow that he was
yarding up, and
which had been
dogged too much.
Gang affiliations give rise to terms such as dog for a member of the Mongrel Mob gang.

Talking is
'barking', to be
called a dog is a
term of respect, and
conversations are
peppered with 'sieg
f ..ing heil' as a
greeting. Patched
members are referred
to as dogs. 'It's
certainly not a
derogatory term
within the mob and
it's used with quite
a lot of respect,'
he said.

The iron "dogs" used
to join the rail and
sleepers during the
construction of the
line in 1928 are
also intact.

He unhappily got on
the logs to knock
out the "dog" that
was holding it to
the raft.

The country is
certainly destitute
of all sorts of
beasts either wild
or tame except Dogs
and Ratts, [sic] the
former are tame and
live with people who
breed and bring them
up for no other
purpose than to eat
...

Author: BOWMAN
Quote:
During the [1890]
strike about 100
seamen unattached in
Port Chalmers stayed
in hotels and
boarding houses, but
a large number of
them found residence
in the "baches" in
what was called
"Sweat Rag Alley",
consisting of a
number of small
baches or cribs in a
double row where the
Corporation Yard now
is. Each bach housed
three or four men
and it was said that
each man had a dog.
From this fact, the
area became known as
"Dogtown".

To the uninitiated
this may mean
nothing, but, to
those in the know,
the quickest way to
cause a riot and to
raise an
insurrection is to
call an inhabitant
of Port Chalmers a
dweller in Dogtown.

Author: CRYER
Quote:
There are two
explanations for the
term Dog Town. The
first has its clue
in the name of the
town, Port Chalmers,
which obviously had
a lot of docks. As
with the Isle of
Dogs in London,
there is a belief
that in the old days
the docks of Port
Chalmers caused it
to be referred to as
Dock Town, and the
word became
corrupted. But there
are also legends
that.. there were
always many seamen
about, sometimes
unemployed, and all
of them were
accompanied by their
dogs. Most of these
men lived in
cottages in George
Street which became
known locally as Dog
Town and the name
spread to mean Port
Chalmers in general.
It's occasionally
heard even today.

Author: STEWART
Quote:
And during the
troubles [sc. an
1890 strike] , about
100 seamen from
other ports stayed
in baches in an area
called 'Sweat Rag
Alley' in Port
Chalmers. I t was
said that each
resident there had a
dog - and the name
'Dogtown'
unfortunately stuck
to the Borough for a
long time.

Most dog trial
people are pretty
decent.
