Author: GORDON
Quote:
There are top
looking rams that
finish up in the dog
tucker paddock
because I know too
much about them.

Mother would draw
out the embers with
a long scraper, and
brush out the [153]
oven with a big
manuka broom dipped
in cold water. ...
After the bread came
out, trays of apples
... would go in to
bake, ... or a
special `dog's cake'
made of pollard,
bran, suet, and
butter-milk.

Author: BAXTER
Quote:
Gandhi ... insisted
on shouting seven
dog's-noses for
Horse in the bar of
the Shamrock.

Author: HYDE
Quote:
`And I wish you
hadn't known what
you say you've
known. Only a lying,
foul-minded swine
like you would have
made it up, anyway
... That's life for
you, Birkett -
dog-brag.'

Mr Tanczos, a failed
leadership
contender, argued
that the majority of
parliament was
opposed to the
dog-chipping
legislation in one
form or another. ..
In the case of
dog-chipping, Labour
was relying on the
Greens' assurances
to shore up its own
postition ...

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
dog-flogger:
musterer's term for
his stick.

mustering stick: dog
flogger. [dog
flogger.]

Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Quote:
Day after day Bert
struggled down there
on the board but it
was dog-hard work.

Author: MAY
Quote:
The country was a
dog-hole ... the
forty-acre system a
most villainous
take-in.

Author: PICKERING
Quote:
By including the old
tin musterers' huts,
the 'dog-kennel'
bivouacs, recognised
rock bivs, rock
overhangs and the
odd sea-cave,
accommodation of
some sort has now
run up to almost a
thousand sites in
the hills.

Author: PICKERING
Quote:
Bivouacs are
shrunken versions of
huts and
affectionately
called dog kennels.

Now our stockyard is
different from most
- the only
substantial part of
it being the gate.
The rest of it is
what is usually
known as 'dogleg'
and is composed of
small logs piled up,
with an occasional
post to keep them
upright. [dog-leg
fence]

the log fence and
the dog-leg are the
cheapest, and most
common on new
clearings.

In fencing we have a
number of different
methods, from the
primitive dog-leg to
the more handsome
and substantial post
and wire.

Author: DONEY
Quote:
Dog-leg is a good
fence and stands two
or three years if
put up properly.

Dog'.leg fence'.
(d&omacr.g'.l&ebreve.g
f&ebreve.ns'.).} A
kind of rough fence,
Dog'.leg
(d&omacr.g'.l&ebreve.g),
n. } made of posts
and rails. Light
posts (about 3 ft. 6
in. in height) are
arranged in pairs,
crosswise, so as to
form a fork about 18
in. from the top.
Each fork supports a
rail, which is laid
slantwise and
plaited in and out
among the three or
four neighbouring
supports, its lower
end being driven
into the ground.
Sometimes the whole
is capped with a
horizontal rail,
laid from fork to
fork.

Author: McKENZIE
Quote:
The `dog-legged'
type of fence ...
was apparently a
purely Canadian type
... made of stakes
of varying length
and the trunks of
small trees.

There was no fencing
wire in those days
[in Auckland ca1865]
so we had to make
what is called a
`dog-leg fence'.
This was composed of
stakes driven
crossways in the
ground and the long
sticks laid with one
end on the ground
and the other end on
the crossed stakes.

Author: WILSON
Quote:
The tiny flower
patch surrounding
the shack was
protected by a
dog-leg fence - that
is a fence of
crooked sticks and
branches held
together by their
own crookedness.

The dog-leg fence,
found in North
America only in the
Maritime Provinces
of Canada,
reappeared in the
Nova Scotian
settlement at Waipu,
and from there
spread to some other
bush settlements in
the north. It was
constructed by
driving two crossing
stakes into the
ground, and in the
notch of these
placing a third rail
which followed the
direction of the
fence ... It was
claimed that it
would keep out
cattle, but the
fence was never
widely adopted
probably because of
its tendency to get
out of repair
easily.

Author: BOSWELL
Quote:
So the farm
gradually took
shape. Small
paddocks were
fenced, first the
crude `dog-leg' of
roughly-split light
posts, then
post-and-rail and
later barbed wire.

dogleg adj. applied
to primitive fence
made of rough
timber.

dog-leg fence NZ &
Austral. zigzag
fence made of logs
supported on crossed
poles.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
doglegged shape of a
crooked fence; from
the proverbially
crooked nature of a
dog's hind leg, now
more familiar in the
dogleg approach to
some golf holes.
NZA.

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
You'll get five
shillings a week
dog-money if your
pup turns out any
good.

Author: BAKER
Quote:
Bojay shook his
[head] and started
dog-paddling.

Author: PRESTON
Quote:
But none of the
blocks showed the
least recovery;
there was no second
growth. In the
Spring we had only
30% of lambs and the
sheep were dog-poor.

... in each of the
Canoes were two or
three Cheifs [sic]
and the habits of
these were superior
to any we had yet
seen, the Cloth they
were made on was of
the best sort and
cover'd on the out
side with Dog skins
put on in such a
manner as to look
agreeable to the
Eye. Few of these
people were tattow'd
or mark'd in the
face like those we
have seen farther to
the south, but
several had their
Backsides tattou'd
much in the same
manner as the
Inhabitants of the
Islands within the
Tropics.

Author: FORSTER
Quote:
they had bits of
dog-skin at the four
corners of their
cloaks.. The
boghee-boghee, or
shaggy-cloak, which
hangs round their
necks like a thatch
of straw, was almost
constantly worn by
them ...

Author: WILKES
Quote:
In his hand [Pomare]
usually carries a
short cloak of
dog-skin, called
topuni, shupuni, or
patutu.

[The Maori men to
the making] of their
prized dog-skin, or
Kiwi-feather,
clothing mats ...

Source: Early Journals of Henry Williams, The
Author: WILLIAMS
Quote:
He stood in silence
leaning on the end
of his musket, a
bill-hook bright as
silver in his belt
in front, and a
handsome dogskin mat
thrown carelessly
over his shoulders,
...

Author: WILKES
Quote:
He was very feeble,
... and clad in an
old dog-skin robe.
Notes: 1840 Mar in 1852 Wilkes U.S. Exploring Expedition 1/307

Author: MACLEAN
Quote:
The elder men were
dressed in their
best dogskin and
kaitaka mats, some
of them had their
heads decorated with
huia and kotuku
feathers, not
neglecting their
mere[es acute]
pounamu (greenstone

Notes: 1848 May 26 Maclean Diary in 1940 Cowan Sir Donald Maclean 36

Quote:
He gave me a dogskin
mat made by the
Ngaticahounas
[Ngatikahungunu].

The early voyagers
and the first
residents of New
Zealand all agree in
stating that the
Maori dog was
unknown in the wild
state. It was a
purely domesticated
species ... valued
... for supplying
the material for
their much prized
dogskin mats ...

Author: COWAN
Quote:
.. Te Rangihaeata
rose, a tall gaunt
savage in
appearance, clothed
in a dogskin mat.

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote:
Apart from
greenstone
heirlooms, etc., the
most valuable gifts
that can be bestowed

Author: IHIMAERA & LONG (ed.)
Quote:
The elders in their
fly-blown dog-skin
mats / yearn for
their smoky whares

[A NZ yachtsman from
Seoul olympic
preliminaries speaks
about racing;] ...
think you're getting
up in the water, but
find you're going
dog-slow.

Author: WHEELER
Quote:
The men, and often
the children too,
sometimes don't
arrive home till
breakfast time,
hungry and
dog-tired.

Author: COWAN
Quote:
I have seen us leave
the station to get
home at seven in the
evening, dog-tired.
Then we would have
to feed the horses,
have our tea and let
the horses out later
on.

Source: High Times in the High Country
Author: KERR
Quote:
On a warm afternoon
these days you might
find three old gents
in my six-hectare
dog-training
paddock.

Source: Big Country of the North Island
Author: NEWTON
Quote:
Frank is a son of
old Seymour Lambert,
once a leading North
Island dog-trial
man. This was Dudley
Bushe, another noted
Gisborne dog-trial
man ...

The trick: how to
make an entertaining
programme without
sacrificing too many
dog-trialing
traditions, to
produce a
dog-trialing
equivalent of
one-day cricket.

He [a horse] had the
most unusual
formline in
yesterday's Te Rapa
racebook - BLORF -
short for brought
down, lost rider not
in the first nine,
ran off and fell.
Laugh as much as you
like, saysWilson,
Blorf isn't ready to
be dog-tuckered.

Author: DAVIS
Quote:
They wandered about
on deck with the
superior yet
slightly baffled
expressions of stud
merinos by some
horrible mistake
drafted in with a
mob of dog-tucker
rams.

The dog tucker shed
stood on four legs
beside the killing
shed.

Did you rattle the
cowboy along this
morning? If so, it's
quite probable that
by tomorrow the
whole district will
have heard how you
murdered him and
hung him up the
dog-tucker tree.

Source: Along the Track: a collection of NZ hunting yarns
Author: AXBEY
Quote:
This went on for a
month or so, until

from fly camping to
find the owner in
residence and our
arch-enemy [a bull]

from the dog-tucker
tree.

Author: PETER
Quote:
A musterer is often
known as a
dog-walloper.

shepherd: a
dog-walloper.

They refer to
themselves as ..
lizards or
dog-wallopers ...

mustering stick :
dog-walloper.

Author: EVANS
Quote:
After this he went
to the West Coast
and worked in the
Blackball mine on

dog watch' because
it was an all-night
shift.

Author: BENNETT
Quote:
All day and all
night there were
miners on [128] the
move: front shift,
back shift and
dogwatch.

Author: SEDDON
Quote:
The younger members
called themselves
`The Dog Watch.' The
debate in the
daytime was
conducted by the
elders. The Dog
Watch took over
after the older
member' day's work
was done.

No.25 81 The late,
late shift (usually
11 p.m. - 7 a.m.)
for despatchers. A
naval term - thought
to have been coined
by those who thought
that particular
watch to be `a dog
of a job'.

Are you reading my
mind Peter? That's
exactly what this
Jewish New Zealander
was about to say.
And there are more
gay men in NZ than
Jews, I'm sure. ..
The whole idea of a
"mainstream New
Zealander" is bogus
anyway .. except as
dogwhistle code for
"real New
Zealander". Which is
why Jordan's
annoyed. And so am
I.

This, say the
critics, is pure
dog-whistle, the
subtle appeal to
racism, sounded at a
pitch that is heard
only by the right
ears.

... what are
sometimes called dog
whistle politics ...

Critics say the pair
- who run
Crosby/Textor, a
public relations and
polling company with
branches in Sydney,
Melbourne, Canberra
and London -
specialise in "dog
whistle politics" -
fearmongering that
preys on racial
disquiet and
prejudice ... Some
say [they] did not
help the
Conservatives, whose
share of the vote
rose less than 1%,
and that the
dog-whistling
backfired. ...

That is a
dog-whistle National
does not want: one
that sends the dog
after rabbits
instead of the ewes.

The net also plays
into the Tories'
hands by
facilitating the
"dog-whistle"
campaigning at which
Michael Howard has
become increasingly
adept. Just as a
dog-whistle is
inaudible to humans
but is heard by
every canine within
miles, Howard has
been beaming
messages at targeted
groups-anti-abortion
campaigners, and
people hostile to
immigrants, gypsies
and
asylum-seekers-which,
if broadcast in the
normal way, might
repel the majority
of voters.
Notes: [the Observer, 10 Apr. 2005] quoted on www.worldwidewords.org/turnsofphrase/tp-dog2htm Not a Kiwi quote

Quote:
On race, however,
Brash has proved a
diligent
dog-whistler.

My house has its
dogable area out the
back, already fenced
off.

When the Arnetts
started, each was
the dog-box boy.

waggons known as
`dog-boxes' ...

Because there was
not enough room for

The guard put the
two dogs in the

A TRENTHAM schoolboy

... Lower Hutt

Mr Connolly, MP,
Dunedin, said:
`Houses for 700
pounds? -
substandard housing,
that's what it is.'
Interjector:
`Dog-boxes, I'd
say.'

Author: McGILL
Quote:
dogbox cramped
quarters, originally

Author: NEWBOLD
Quote:
DOG BOX (n) Prison
official's office.

Author: Newbold
Quote:
Dog-boxes are just
steel cubicles with
perspex windows and
bars, so that the
screws inside them
were as much
prisoners as we
were.

Author: NEAVE
Quote:
Later, traction
engines [for
threshing] ... had
their own galley and
cook, and it was a
great sight to see
engine, mill,
water-cart and dog
box - a two wheeled

Water Joey slept
near the machinery
to be handy to get
up steam in the
morning, and then
get the cookshop
going.

Nearly all the
[Otago fishing-]
boats are fitted
with good cabins and
weather-dodgers, the
open boat with only
a dog-box over the
engine having fallen
into disuse.

Quote:

LATICEPS. Dumeril.
Dog Fish.

Cephaloscyllium laticeps, Dumeril. The dog-fish is very common.

Author: WILSON
Quote: DOGFISH: ,see Stargazer Ibid. 208 SPOTTED STARGAZER Similar to his cousin the Common Stargazer but thicker and with more distinctive, spotted markings on body and fins. ... Other names are Catfish, Monkfish and Dogfish.

Department marine
ecologist Clinton
Duffy said it was

dogfish.

Quote:
All the coves of

fish of various

and large

Among the

Ibid. 1/322 Many other fish are equally numerous, answering to our hakes, tench, bream, snapper, haddock, elephant-fish, pollock, salmon, gurnards, pipe-fish, parrot-fish, leather-jackets, cole-fish, John Dorys, sword-fish, cod; various kinds of skate and cat-fish, sting-ray and dog-fish.

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote: The Shark is rarely seen near the coast, though small Dog-fish, from one to three feet in length, are very common, and considered excellent food by the natives

Quote:
Great numbers of
large dogfish
prevail.

Dyer says the
Dogfish (a small

He was chased by one

having gone into the

After this we came
to a long row of
poles, on which was
hung an immense
supply of dried
shark (the dogfish
split in two),
besides baskets of
ku-me-ras (sweet
potatoes), ...
Dogfish of more than one species furnish good edible food.
dogfish. The name used in Australia and New Zealand for different kinds of fish of the shark family. b. Emissola spp. TH

Author: POWELL
Quote: GUMMY SHARK OR DOGFISH (Emissola antarctica), Manga of the Maoris, grows up to 3 1/2 feet in length ...

Source: Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
Author: FORSTER
Quote: They caught a very large Dogfish. Ibid. 2/269 The day before, the greater Dog fish, (Squalus cogris), well described by Mr Pennant in his Br. Zool. Vol. III. was caught, & likewise a new kind of Codfish, [[ed. fn] Gadus bachus of Descr. Anim., p.120.] it has 2 dorsal-fins, & one beard under the Chin, a dark back, but is allover reddish, & even under the belly & on the fins. I had got such another red Codfish some days before ...

Author: NATUSCH
Quote: Family SQUALIDAE Includes two species of Squalus , the brown ( S. blainvillei ) and spotted ( S. acanthias ) dogfishes; one species of Scymnodon (S. plunketi ), which grows up to 5 ft long and is also known as the brown dogfish; one species of Centrophorus (C. squamosus); one species of Centrophorus (C. squamosus); one species of the long-snouted Deania (D. calcea); one of Scymnodalatias , a genus in which the spine is missing; two luminescent sharks of the genus Etmopterus ; and two of Centroscymnus . Of these squalid sharks, Squalus is the most commonly caught.

Mustelus antarcticus. Synonyms: Galeus antarcticus and Galeorhinus antarcticus. The smooth-hound, or gummy (Mustelus antarcticus) ... is one of the small sharks commonly taken by trawlers around new Zealand, and popularly termed `dogfish.' The family is distinguished by the blunt pavement-like teeth - hence the popular name `gummy,' in use in Australia, where the species is also common.
71 Mustelus antarcticus: Common dogfish, pioke (Auckland), rigg (Canterbury).

Galeorhinus australis. Synonyms: Galeus canis (in part); Galeus australis; Mustelus australis; Eugaleus australis. The southern tope, or school shark, Galeorhinus australis, is one of the small so-called dogfish commonly taken by trawlers around New Zealand.

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: Spined Dogfish Shark Koinga lebruni (Vaillant) (Syn. Squalus kirki Phillipps, S. canis Forster, and S. maculatus Richardson) ... Spiny Dogfish Shark Oxynotus brunienis (Ogilby)

Quote:
The gang that year
was the most capable
and strongly dogged

with.

Quote:
Early November found
me riding up country
once again, newly
dogged and horsed.

Quote:
One thing I can say
is that the
musterers of today
are better dogged
and are more capable
in the actual
handling of stock ..
they were a strongly
dogged and capable
gang.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
I struck what was
probably the
strongest and
best-dogged gang
I've mustered with
at Mesopotamia.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
A first-class
musterer, always
strongly dogged ...

Author: NEWTON
Quote: The gang that year [1932-1935] was the most capable and strongly dogged I have ever worked with. Ibid. 89 Early November found me riding up country again newly dogged and horsed.

Quote:
Old Jack Kidd ...
had the place when I
was first there. He
wasn't very strongly
dogged and, of
course, that didn't

called Wad -

Author: BOOTH
Quote:
[The pie-cart owner]
clattered a cup and
saucer ... `Like a
doggie to go with
it?' Darlon nodded
and two minutes

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
By crikey ...
wouldn't it be great
to collect all the
cigarette butts
chucked away at the

home? Remember all

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
Fibres responsible
for dogginess have
been traced to
follicles that show
a grossly enlarged
outer root sheath
just above the
follicle bulb.

The importance of
dogginess as a fault
of course depends on
the manufacturing
performance of the
wool and the
characteristics of
the fabric made from
it. The association
between very high
yolk production and
dogginess in New
Zealand wool is
apparently an
artificial one.

Author: MCGREGOR
Quote:
Some huntaways are

and can cause

and bunching of
stock .. Ken Spence
warns against all
unnecessary dogging
and bunching of
sheep.

Source: High Times in the High Country
Author: KERR
Quote:
My first dogging job
was at Glenlappa
Station, from 1943.

Author: BARDSLEY
Quote:
Usually, we'd be
absolutely doggo and
went to bed early.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
The most outstanding
feature of doggy
wool is a wider and
more shallow crimp
than is normal for
wool of equivalent
fineness. A
secondary feature of
some doggy wools is
a very lustrous
appearance. So far
doggy wool has
attracted notice
only in Merino wool
and wool from breeds
with Merino in their
ancestry.

Author: MAF
Quote:
Doggy: Lacking a
defined staple

No compensation let

/ Give us strength;

Author: TURNER
Quote:
The present
colloquial ... use
of dollar, usually
in half a dollar,
`half a crown' in
New Zealand, but in
Australia, where
half-crowns are not
in use, two
shillings, should
help the natural
adoption of the new
official term

The crown was called
a bull, a cartwheel,
a caser, five bob,
and most familiar of
all a dollar, the
latter dating from
the time when the
rate of exchange was
four US dollars to
the pound. The only
instance recorded of
Cockney rhyming
slang term for a
coin is Oxford
scholar, the
derivation from
dollar being
obvious. The half
crown was called a
half-dollar, a
half-bull,
half-caser,
two-and-a-kick, and
two-and-a-buck. In
the latter instance
buck stands for
sixpence, though
apparently this term
was rarely used by
itself for that coin
denomination, but
almost always in
association with a
number of shillings.
The florin seems to
have had fewer
English nicknames,
only two bob being
recorded as being in
use in New Zealand.

Down to Wellington
we travel, M.H.R.
and M.L.C.,/ Where
we blow the
hard-earned dollars
of our bleeding
counteree./

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Pitching games were
Pitch and Toss,
Quoits, Ninepins,
Egg Cap and
Toodle-em-buck. In
the game of
Toodle-em-buck
(Richmond ([19]19) a
piece of broom a
foot in length with
a button on top of
it stood upright in
a circle of about
two fet in diameter.
Players pitched
another piece of
broom at this
upright stick from a
set distance in an
endeavour to knock
it over and send the
button out of the
circle. The game was
played to the cry of
`Roll up, Tumble up,
come and play the
game of
Toodle-em-Buck'.
There is still
occasional mention
of Egg Cap (Horoeka,
Alexandra).

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote: Another universal stone-throwing game was Ducks and Drakes (K-8), or Skipping Stones, which consisted simply in `skipping' flat stones across the water. feet in diameter and a button was placed on top of the stick. Players pitched another piece of broomstick of the same size at the upstanding piece in an attempt to knock it over and send the button outside the circle. The game was played to the cry of `Roll up, tumble up, come and play the game of Toodlle-em-buck.' Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
dopey or dozey: a
ewe which loses
interest in life is
said to go dopey.
Usually she has been
suffering the lack
of a steadily rising
nutritional plane
during her pregnancy
and often is
carrying twins. Her
disease is thus
sometimes termed
twin-lamb disease.
More correctly it is
pregnancy toxaemia.
[dozey]

Dopie. A sheep which
loses condition and
interest in life, is
said to go d[opie].
(C.)

.. antepartum
paralysis or
"dopiness" of ewes
is a nutritional
disease definitely
associated, as a
rule, with ewes
falling off in
condition at the
approach of lambing.

The troubles which
are most likely to
affect the ewes are
(i) ante-partum
paralysis, or as the
farmer more
frequently calls it
'dopiness'
'twin-lamb disease'
or 'sleeping
sickness' ...

All good
sheepfarmers know
that 'sleepy
sickness'
('dopiness') in ewes
can be prevented by
proper feeding at
the right time.

The worst soils for
`dopiness' as the
local farmers call
the disease [sc.
bush-sickness].

Recent
investigations ion
New Zealand testify
to ... the value of
top dressing of
pastyures with lime
and superphosphate
where sheep are
affected with
dopiness diseases.

The known deficiency
diseases in New
Zealand apparently
mainly due to the
lack of some element
in the food of farm
animals are:- `Bush
Sickness' or
[mistakenly] Iron
deficiency.
`Dopiness' or
Calcium deficiency.
`Waihi Disease' or
Phosphate
deficiency. `Goitre'
or Iodine
deficiency... Bush
sickness is always
found in the
volcanic district on
coarse rhyolitic
pumice soils and
`dopiness' on soils
derived from fine
volcanic dust or mud
showers. A soil on
which `dopiness'
develops is a
leached loam and is
found on
deteriorated lands,
i.e., lands which
originally were
highly fertile due
to the ashes from
the `bush burn,' the
land subsequently
becoming gradually
less productive ...

It is at
lambing-time that
the effect of
grass-grub ravages
is most severe. Ewes
are low in condition
and have missed the
`green bite from the
pastures ... The
normal green-feed
area ... is
inadequate. The
result is a high
mortality in young
lambs, an increased
susceptibility of
the ewe to
`dopiness,' ...

Some green,
succulent feed just
before and at
lambing assists in
the prevention of
diseases associated
with lambing -
dopiness (twin lamb
disease or
ante-partum
paralysis) and milk
fever.

She'll be back at
the strip-tease
stuff, dopo.

.. it affords a
distinguishing

and 'dopy' country.

The Dorper sheep
breed isn't exactly
bald but has a
mixture of wool and
hair which keeps
their bottom nice
and clean... The
Dorper breed was
developed in South
Africa in the late
1930s by crossing
Blackhead Persian
and Dorset Horn
breeds. They are
solid white or white
with a black head
and don't require
shearing.

New Zealand's latest

from South Africa,

Stewart Island -

in a tin can. It was
round the store [in
the ?1960s] we would
have our first late
October battle with
lighted Tom Thumbs
and Double Happys.

Author: JONES
Quote:
Guy Fawkes night,
double-happys
exploded in her
metal letter box.

`I had a fair idea
it was lightning.
There was a roar
like a double happy
(fire cracker) going
off inside a rubbish
bin'

Does it mean that
the protestors
approve Communist
Chinese doctrines,
the thoughts of Mao
- and the Nanking
nuclear
double-happy.

[Hdg] A night to
make you double
happy... This year's
15-minute fireworks
hatbour spectacular
explodes into life
at 9pm on October
[sic] 5...

A "double long", or
"doppio espresso"
has two shots of
coffee for a full
cup.

What'll be next to
your bed when you
waken in the
morning?.. Foot
falcons or dubble
[sic] pluggers.

Double shearing was
begun originally
because of trouble
with blackberry ...

Ted Lawrence has
tried double
shearing in order to
avoid the hay/wool
clash, but found it
wasn't worthwhile,
as the lambs still
had to be shorn in
December.

The difficulties of
acquiring labour,
due to high wages
offering in mines
and sawmills, make
double shearing a
problem for most
farmers.

Source: In the Wake of the Axe
Author: NEWTON
Quote:
With lambs and
double-shearing
35,000 sheep were
shorn last year ...

Source: In the Wake of the Axe

.. everything is

[double-shearing]

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The

... state houses

double up shed (40
cups.)

In addition to [day
cards] the

elusive [heading]

Author: GRAY

`Giving you your bit
is she, then? She'd
be a double banger I

Simon blushed
...`She's all

Once a

There would be the

There the teams

The doctor came to

Needle double-banked

the hut. He must

in the river. ... he
was asked `Where's
the Needle?' He
replied `In Hell!'

Author: SCANLAN
Quote: As children they had walked along it to school, before they had a pony, on which they`double-banked'. Ibid. 52 They were ready and waiting when the three children returned from school, riding one behind the other on a fat Shetland pony. They still called it `double-banking' though young Nicholas had been added to the load at the beginning of the year.

Ruefully he noticed
a pal ... sitting on
his well-groomed
chestnut galloway.
`Reg,' called Jim,
`double bank me to
the start, the
blankey drag has
gone'.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
... and as the horse

shepherd had to
leave the cook ...
and head ... for
another horse.

double-bank vb.
Austral. inf. to
carry a second
person on (a horse,
bicycle, etc.).

My brother Jack made

horse.

Quote:
As children they had
walked along it to
school, before they
had a pony, on which
they
`double-banked'.

Of course you soon
learned to
double-bank and take
your girl-friend for
a spin on a
Saturdayafternoon.

Of course you soon
learned to
double-bank and take
your girl-friend for
a spin on a
Saturdayafternoon.

And the growlers
double-bank him/ In

[sic] fight.

One of my earliest

[?c1890s-1900s] ...

One double banger

...' ... `Two

Double-banked. ...'

Quote:
`I offered Mrs.
Swift a double-bank

Whitton whispered in

Some were on foot,
some what is called
'double-banking.'

Buggies in those
days were almost
unknown, and fully
half the visitors
arrived on
horseback, many of
the younger class
'double-banking.'

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
And as the horse was

An old grey mare was

had to double-bank
behind the saddle.

Quote:
He bought them a

other riders.

We were riding
double-banked when

Two boys.. who were

May Taylor and

[Hdg] Double-banking
on motor cycles.

I saw numbers of
children on their
way tothe public
school... Some of

some what is called
"double-banking" on

Times were harder
still for many of

children from the
backblocks,
double-banking on a

Unless new

Quote:

if necessary to

JOHN (Sings) ... No
more double-bunking
double-bunking,

We are all familiar
with the
'double-decker'

The mob were started
over [the ford] but
the double-deckers,
those with two

An eight-stand

It [the truck] was a

divided into 16

Quote:
The modern livestock
truck will carry 600

decker can

This was the first

to carry a

Quote:
The mob were started

deckers, [26] those

A hermit [sheep]
must be
distinguished from a
`double-decker',
which is simply a
sheep that had
missed the muster
once and
consequently had a
double layer of
wool.

Up in the mountains,

proudly succeeded in
rounding up
twenty-odd old
hermits, defiant
woolly sheep also
known as `double
deckers', which had
been wily enough to
dodge last season's
muster.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
In the wool boom in
1951 an orchardist
in Hamilton had five
"double-decker"
sheep in his orchard
(they'd missed one
shearing and had a
double crop of
wool)... Being
double deckers each
sheep clipped close
to twenty pounds.

Some of the
double-deckers [sc.
trams] run on the
long routes... All
the provision that
is made for smokers
on double-decker
cars is needed.

These trams are all
what we call double
deckers, and it is
the fashion in
Christchurch for the
ladies to ride on
the top instead of
inside, so that on a
summer's day these
vehicles present a
very gay and
flower-like
appearance

The double-decker
must go.

Whatever the Company
may think of the
recommendations to
abolish the
double-decker cars,
the proposal is one
that finds
considerable
sympathy with the
travelling public.

Another treat was
the ride on a
double-decker tram
to Island Bay.

... the
double-dumped
scoured wool was
given an extra
passage through the
willey.

Author: DICK
Quote:
. We're shearing the
double-fleece
stragglers.'

Most of the sheep
went on, except

double-fleece sheep

scrubyard.

Got some
double-fleece rams
off The Mistake.

If I don't get these
sheep shorn they

double-fleece.

Author: DICK
Quote:
We're shearing the
double-fleece
stragglers.

Looking out for
double-fleeced
sheep.

Double-fleeced sheep
were the chief
sufferers, the bird
[kea] getting hold

After a number of
years, when sheep
were mustered in
from the back
ranges, it was
noticed that several
would die in the
yards ..., for they
would require to be
kept in for drafting
on the following
day. These dead
sheep would be
mostly sheep which
had missed a
shearing, and were
double-fleeced,
having very long
wool.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH

We lived on wild
pig, wild beef shot
on Kaiwaka, and the
fat wild sheep and
double-fleecers that
could be raked in
from river cliffs
...

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
If your dogs worked
well, it was a good
day, and if you came
back with a glow of
pride to tell how
the little bitch
caught a mob of
"double-fleecers"
down the back spur
and fetched them
right round onto the
front face.

Author: VANCE
Quote:
Waters snow-raked a
mob of twenty
double-fleecers out
of the high basin of
Separation Creek.

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
If amongst them
there are some
"woollies" or
"double-fleecers"
which had escaped in

still.

Quote:
Double fleecers are
more tricky, as they
are likely to have
had some real
practice in
deliberately
escaping the muster.

As we mustered the
various blocks, all
the double-fleecers

driven through the

On the missing man's
property 18 months
later a musterer
chased a
double-fleecer under

over a stream.

Author: LOUGHNAN

double-gate:
referring to a
drafting race having
two gates so that

into any one of
three check-pens.
Very occasionally
one may find a
triple-gate race;
and many saleyards
boast, halfway along
the race, a second
pair of gates for
another man.

Author: HYDE

A double-header is
the term for
catching two fish on
different hooks at
the same time.

Author: WILSON

`He began drinkin'

Then he goes on
drinking these
double 'eaders, but
he don't get noisy,
just ... glaring
round the bar ...'

`One for the road.
But make mine a

Notes: c1962 Baxter Horse (1985) (Name and the Game) 25

Fancy watching

Of particular

soon turned to
`double-headers' as

... semi-darkness of

[The liquor] fired
[the Maoris']
imagination ...
Panic and fear is

not long before
several of the gang
became `pannikin
struck'.

Sometimes two

double-header: a

Some of the typical
terms used in
marbles referred to
the act of shooting
and the movement of
the marbles. Those
related to ways of
shooting marbles
were cribbing,
firsts, fudging,
funks, funnicks,
funnigans, flunks,
forces, knee-high,
knuckle-down-stiff,
knuckles, and lasts.
Terms connected with
the movement of the
marbles were:
cannons, clears,
dead-stick,
double-hits, fires,
funs, gees,
haystacks, in smug,
keeps, kills,
kisses, lay-ups,
manyes, ones, pink,
ringer, rolls, scat,
screws, skinned,
skun, spiders,
sported-off, stays,
stops, tracks,
throughs.

Sometimes we'd lift
our [crayfish] pots
twice in the same
day - double-picking
we called it.

.. with the
introduction of
double ridgers, this
[ridging] is
gradually being
overcome ...

The seed (2lb of
kale and half lb of
turnip seed to the
acre) and manure
were planted through
the double-ridger.

Source: In the Wake of the Axe
Author: NEWTON
Quote:
Otui double-shore
that year and Bob
was there for
practically the
whole season.

Source: In the Wake of the Axe
Author: NEWTON
Quote:
.. the practice has
been to double-shear
everything ...

He would fill up
about eight or ten

we used to call
'double stripers'
with crays and sew

He'd get 2/6 for a
sack. That was back
in the late 1920s
through till about
1935.

Author: DEVANNY
Quote:
Sometimes two
pennies are filed
down to half their
thickness and then
joined together. A
double-tailer is
called a 'grey'; a
double-header a
'nob.

Quote: I was very annoyed and went around referring to Kapua as a weak mug and a double-yolker. Ibid. 248 DOUBLE-YOLKER. (n) Stupid person, buffoon. See also EGG.

Better still if it
turned up on the
plate as a perfectly
poached
double-yolker.

a ewe known to be
carrying twin lambs
- a double-yolker.

Dry humour runs
thick through
through this
collection; for
example ..
double-yolker - a
ewe carrying twins.

doublebeak 975

Author: MCMEEKAN
Quote:
.. there are two
lines of
walk-through sheds,
the single and the
doubled-up. The
single has one set
of cups for each
pair of bails, while
the doubled-up has
two sets of cups per
pair.

The ideal number of
sets of cups for
each milker in a
doubled-up
herringbone is six.

Milking.. is carried
on in a 20-bail
doubled-up shed in
which 2 men handle 9
sets of cups each.

Author: MONEY
Quote:
Taking turn about at
the duty of
shouldering the
stretchers, we
reached the
Wangangaro Redoubt
early in the
afternoon, and we
were served out with
a `doubler,' or two
lots of grog in one.

Author: OGILVIE
Quote:
For good measure the
distillate would be
put through a
`doubler' for
further refinement
and strengthening.
At this stage a
copper `worm' was
used to lead the
vapour to its
condensation point.

Doubling is fun and
we ride two and
three abreast.

Author: STEAD
Quote:
He remembers
'doubling' her on
his bike down to
Bridge Avenue for a
swim, her black hair
in his mouth,

Author: FOOTE
Quote:
They tried doubling.
As anyone who has
experienced it will
know, doubling for
any distance is
mighty hard on the
posterior of the one
on the bar.

All cows and heifers
near profit caused
keen competition,
whilst backward and
doubtful calves were
hard to quit.

Author: STACEY
Quote:
The packmen left and
were replaced by
'no-hoper dough
roasters' which did
little to alleviate
the problem so they
were replaced ...

Author: PETER
Quote: dough-roaster: cook.

station cook:
dough-roaster
[dough-roaster]

Author: SCOTT
Quote:
Ned Ryan and Pat
McPhee.. Sat down to
Christmas dinner of
pork, doughboys and
billy-made tea.

In it there are pork
bones and
watercress,
doughboys and
potatoes - a treat
for the bros who
will pay $7 each to
eat it with a
plastic fork off a
polystyrene plate.

Spread an old
newspaper on the
floor andon it place
a steaming pot of
puha,kamo-kamo,
riwai,
brisket-on-the-bone
anddumplings what we
call: doughboys.

The title Doughboy
comes from
thetraditional Maori
boiler, a pot of
puha,pork bones,
potatoes and a lump
of wetdough, broken
into little round
balls,thrown in.
These little
dumplings arecalled
doughboys
(Mutumutu), and by
somecruel of happy
fate, depending on
how youlook at it,
this has become one
Maorislang name for
gays.

Dough boys,
"sinkers," or "water
boys" are prepared
in exactly the same
manner as damper,
except that the
dough need not be so
stiff.

Author: TUWHARE
Quote:
She would make
doughboys to go with
the kamo-kamo.

Author: HUNT
Quote:
Doughboys, that's
what they're called,
but we called them
buggers afloat.

"Maori language has
been my bread and
butter - or my boil
up and dough boys -
for the last four or
five years," he
says.

Nor do you get much
more Victorian (or
rather Elizabethan)
than the miti-miti
or dough-boy
dumpling which comes
with the Paua Bar's
boil-up, along with
the usual meaty pork
bones, some nicely
cooked kumara and
potato, a little of
the cooking juices,
and puha - or in
this case
watercress, lightly
boiled in deference
to modern tastes.

Author: BURNETT
Quote:
As for myself after
a glorious feast
last night of
potatoes, bacon,
doughboys, and
sweetenedcoffee, as
I sat up in my
sleeping-bag, ...
Notes: 1860 March Burnett Diary in 1948 Von Haast Julius Von Haast 87

Author: WALKER
Quote:
Fortunately we had
brought a bucket
..., so we could
make doughboys and
cook some bacon on
our knives.

Author: MILLER
Quote:
Sometimes the flour
is made into
dough-boys - that
is, the flour is
made into dough and
then rolled into
balls about the size
of your fist.

Author: MONEY
Quote:
We had a billy of
`skilligolee' to
warm us up while the
... dough-boys ...
were being got under
weigh.

Author: ELWELL
Quote:
... the black cook
always had a good
supply of meat and
`dough-boys'

Fried chops and
`dough boys', the
latter being simply
flour mixed with
water, and fried ...

Source: Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ
Author: HARPER
Quote:
.. we could only
afford two small
`dough-boys' - or
suet dumplings - for
each meal

One might have
scraped gum and
cooked `doughboys'
among less
interesting
surroundings than
those of the
diggers' camp.

Author: KENWAY
Quote:
flapjack and a
doughboy (dumpling)
...

Doughboy: A dumpling
made of flour, sugar
and suet, boiled. It
was a favourite dish
out mustering. (C.)

Author: EVANS
Quote:
They bought rice and
a little flour to
make doughboys ...

I was always eating
... And I loved
doughboys, which are
small balls of
flour, usually eaten
with puwha. ...
Notes: 1970 Ihimaera in 1977 NZ Listener Short Stories 86

Author: TUWHARE
Quote:
my favourite niece
said she would make/
dough-boys to go
with the kamo-kamo,
the meat/ and the
puha ... [sic]

dumplings containing
raisins, cooked in
camp oven. see
Buggers Afloat
Notes: 1980 Jan 17 2YA Christine Hunt Stones From Takaka 12:45

Quote:
Then, I'd roll out
my threadbare
Whaariki/ - to help
you remember to take
your boots/ off -
spread an old
newspaper on the
floor/ and on it
place a steaming pot
of puha,/ kamo-kamo,
riwai,
brisket-on-the-bone
and/ dumplings what
we call: doughboys.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
doughboy dumpling of
flour, sugar and
suet, a favourite
when out mustering;
in America it is
flour and
rice-based. NZA.

All excess members
of the poultry yard
were were eaten, ...
or the older ones
converted into a
midweek stew with
... perhaps herb
flavoured `dough
boys' on top.

Author: GEE
Quote:
We ... run home
through the twilit
streets into the
kitchen - doughboy
and stew.

Author: PICKERING
Quote:
Doughboys are
dumpling-like
globules of flour
and baking powder,
milk and water,
dropped into stews
and cooked. Neither
damper nor doughboys
feature greatly on
modern menus.

Like many Maori, the
Tamiheres called
these flour and suet
dumplings
"doughboys". Another
Irish culinary
inheritance, the
doughboys were used

doughnut
round-patterned

Dover: [1898 Morris
Austral-English]
gives the meaning as
a clasp knife.
George McMillan, who
came out in 1858,
told me that when he
arrived it was the
custom for hands to
find theirown knife,
fork, spoon, plate,
and pannikin, which
were all called
dovers. A man would
offer work for `a
pound a week and the
run of my dovers'.
The expression died
out in Canterbury
before 1860.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
Once, in lamenting
inevitable changes,
a runholder
exclaimed, `I wish I
were back in a
maimai with a plate
of bark and a
dover!' The saying
then [ca1870] in
engaging a hand was
`so much a week and
the run of the
dover.' The dover
was a Dover knife,
and the `run of the
dover' was as as
much food as one
could eat.

He said `I tell you
what, Johnson, these
big houses are a
curse instead of a
blessing. I wish I
was back in a
`maimai' with a
plate of bark and a
dover!' The saying
then in regard to
wages was `So much
the week and the run
of the dover.' (The
`dover' was a
DoverKnife and the
`run of the dover'
was as much food as
you liked to eat)

Author: KERSE
Quote:
This `big house'
[built of slabs in
1860] ... was very
draughty and McNab
at a time when he
was suffering from a
bronchial ailment,
was heard to remark
..., `I tell you
what, Johnson, these
big houses are a
curse. I wish I were
back in the maimai
with a plate of bark
and a run of the
dover'.
Notes: [a1890 in] 1984 Knapdale Run 18 [Alexander McNab: had Australian experience]

Quote:
dover n. a clasp

dover: An old brand
of hand shears, and
soon used as another
name for the shears
themselves, hence
such terms as `the
run of your dover'
and flashing your
dover'. [This needs
checking. He may
have go this from
Wilkes.]

Author: MCNAB

of 1914-18, when the
New Zealanders who
fought in the
ill-starred
Gallipoli campaign
were referred to as
`the men from Down
Under', but that was
not the start of it.
This faraway land,
it seems, was known
as `Down Under' in
some parts of
England and Scotland
before the birth of
the present century.
The first World War
merely [put] the
expression into
wider usage. An
Auckland artist, Mr
Trevor Lloyd,made it
the subject of one
of his cartoons at
the very beginning
of that great
upheaval, and at
least one English
war correspondent
used the term when
writing on
Gallipoli. After the
year 1918 the
expression fell into
disuse, but during
the second World War
it again became
popular, and I think
we must thank the
Americans for its
revival. ... In
England it is also
known as the
Antipodes.

Author: BIDWILL
Quote: As we went on, the land became more and more barren and level, till it became a mere moor, without a shrub, and almost without vegetation; a few bushes of the miserable-looking Dracophyllum being all that occurred to break the monotony of the plain. Ibid. 100 I here first saw the great Dracophyllum; it formed a small tree about six inches in diameter, and twenty feet high; it is one of the most curious plants in the world; the leaves grow in tufts at the ends of the branches, just as in the dragon tree (Dracaena), and are the same shape, but in this species they are elegantly reflexed, like the feathers of a soldier's plume; they are a foot long and an inch broad at the base.

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote:
The forest [near

tawai (Leiospermum
racemosum), miro,
and hinau; the
Dracophyllum, which

size of a small
tree, and the
reddish leaves of
which render it a
very remarkable and
beautiful shrub, was
... to be met with.
We followed deer tracks zigzagging up through snow totara and Dracophyllum, then plugged up through soft snow to Brodrick Pass (5,308ft.), taking nearly two hours from camp.

Ibid. 162 The climax came to a head, when on a draft of stud ewes paddocked handy and pushed in on the late afternoon, to make a handy mob before Saturday half-day gave all a welcome respite from duty. `... My extra choice store lambs are [pound]1 per head'. That evening a Mr. Wright ... asked casually if an offer could be procured of 800 to 1000 lambs for immediate fattening. `Yes,' said Jim, `I know of a draft,' roughly describing same. ...' `I leave to-morrow for Fielding [sic] to attend a sheep sale there, and may pick up some suitable fattening lambs.'

He obtained the good
average of 49
guineas for his
draft.

Draft: (i) To divide
stock into classes,
either in a yard or

out (q.v.). In the
old days sheep were
hand drafted, i.e.
lifted over a rail
or manhandled
through agate.

in Canterbury
Settlement],p.135)
About 1864 it was
found possible to

drafting race and
move a single gate
as they came, so
drafting into two
lots. See double
gate. Cattle are
usually now drafted
in a stock-yard
(q.v.). See also
shed. (G.P. W.) (ii)
A number of stock

Notes: 1879 Feb 27 T.C. Kiernan Diary in 1921 Guthrie Smith Tutira 127

Author: MOWAT
Quote:
Drafted up small
poor wethers.

Author: MOWAT
Quote:
Drafted up most from
No 3 and 4.

Author: MOWAT
Quote:
Brought sheep in,
picked out the tops,
then drafted up some
odds and ends.

It being too late to
get down the river
tonight I only
crossed the drafted
cattle over one
stream and took them
on one mile.

Draft'.er
(dr&adot.ft'.&etilde.r),
n. One who drafts;
esp., one who
separates sheep into
flocks in a drafting
yard.

drafter n. man
engaged in drafting
cattle.

.. the carcase was
bruised through the
drafter having
pulled the wool of
the lambs.

Drafters, like Alex
Guy, are experts in
their field and use
their ability and
experience to ensure
maximum returns.

At the height of
their working
season, drafters are
intensely busy.

The drafter couldn't
believe that we
hadn't touched them
apart from docking
them.

Author: STACEY
Quote:
The drafter's arms
work the gate as
though computerised.

A number still use a
stock agent. If you
are using an agent
you should check the
consistency and
accuracy of your
drafter against the
killing sheets.

They were drafted
commercially, and
the drafter didn't
know if he was
taking a lamb from a
little ewe or a big
one.

Author: WATERS
Quote:
He would arrive at a
farm in his gig, tie
the horse up to a
fence and get on
with the drafting.

Author: WATERS
Quote:
Be it understood the
drafting of fat
stock for the
overseas market can
not be done by the
man in the street.

Author: DREAVER
Quote:
When the shearers
knocked off, there
would still be
drafting and
shedding up for the
musterers and we
would all get home
for a very late tea.

Finished drafting
and when we came to
take the rams out
... we found 40 of
them had nocked down
a rail ...

Author: PEACHE
Quote:
Think some got out
as made out there
were 14,000 in hand
after drafting.
Notes: 1883 Jan 21 Peache Jnl in 1970 Gray Quiet with the Hills 63

Author: WILLIAMS & REEVES
Quote:
drafting, culling,
cutting and tailing
[etc]

.. whenever the mobs
were mustered for
...shearing or
drafting, these
`cranky' [that is a
genetically
shortwinded race of
sheep of Strath
Taieri] (as they
came to be called)
were left behind.

On a cattle-run the
tasks of mustering
and drafting the
stock and branding
the youngsters are
very heavy work,
needing the display
of considerable
powers of rough-
riding among
thehorsemen; while
on a sheep-run the
lambing and shearing
seasons tax every
power of the
station-hands.

After a number of
years, when sheep
were mustered in
from the back
ranges, it was
noticed that several
would die in the
yards ..., for they
would require to be
kept in for drafting
on the following
day. These dead
sheep would be
mostly sheep which
had missed a
shearing, and were
double-fleeced,
having very long
wool.

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Quote:
The yards were small
and inconvenient,
and of a temporary
character, and the
work of drafting was
difficult.

Author: CARR
Quote:
A new hand ... is
wise investing in a
good huntaway or a
heading dog. He can
practice [sic] on
the `killers' i.e.
the sheep kept handy
for station use, or
better still, a good
noisy yard dog, as
allstation hands are
liable to be called
upon to assist in
drafting, etc.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
One who was present
has told me of a
cattle drafting on
the Beaumont Run,
above Wrey's Bush.
... what with
cutting-out the
beasts wanted,
rounding-up the
remainder, dodging
wild charging
brutes, ... there
was some ...
exciting work done
that day.

drafting n. NZ &
Austral. drawing off
or selecting
livestock for
particular purpose;
drafting gate
swing-gate at end of
drafting race;
drafting pen pen to
hold selected
animals; drafting
race narrow alley
down which animals
are driven for
drafting.

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
Four-way drafting is
a feature of the
design.

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
The sheep are also
more easily seen by
the man on the
drafting gate when
walking up hill.

In drafting one
sheep witness
thought wasaccused's
ran into his lot and
witnesscould not
catch it at the
drafting gate.

Author: RIVES
Quote:
After dinner we
draughted out
strangers and woolly
ones and a devilish
hard job I had
standing at one of
the draughting gates
counting out the
woolly ones.

Drafting gates 3ft.
wide.

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote:
In later years we
had stockyards at
different parts of
the Station where
the drafting was
done. The cattle
were driven up a
narrow race, with
double gates at the
further end, which
were worked by a man
standing on a
platform. These
yards were specially
built for handling
wild cattle, and had
narrow gaps between
the hinge of the
drafting gate and
post, through which
a man could escape
from a charging
beast.

Author: ACLAND
Quote:
He could hardly tell
his own buggy horses
... and would never
take the drafting
gate ...

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
DRAFTING: The main
feature of
sheepyards is the
drafting race. This
race, perhaps eight
yards in length, is
only wide enough for
sheep to pass
through in single
file; at the end of
the race are two
swinging gates which
can be manipulated
to turn the sheep
into different
yards, and so
separate them into
different `lines' or
mobs.

drafting-gate A gate
used in separating
cattle and sheep
into classes or
herds.

drafting gate n.
gate used to
separate sheep or
cattle

Author: FERNANDEZ
Quote:
The boss was there
working the drafting
gate - two-tooths to
the left-hand gate,
six-tooths to the
right.

Draft: Removing
certain animals from
a group. This can be
done by driving the
animals out of a
group (cut off or
drift off) or
driving them up a
race and removing
them through a
special gate
(drafting gate).
-->to remove certain
animals from a group
driving the animals
out of a group (cut
off or drift off) or
driving them up a
race and removing
them through a
special gate
(drafting gate).

Author: CAIRD
Quote:
.. men have to go in
on foot to force the
animals through
drafting gates ...

Drafting gates 3 ft
wide.

Source: Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock
Author: MILLS ET AL
Quote:
As the man at the
drafting gates is
practically
indispensable, the
man filling the
crush pen is largely
responsible for
keeping an even flow
of sheep going up
the race.

Author: MALLOCH
Quote:
For 65 years he
raddled lambs for
that firm and even
in his 80s he could
be seen clutching
the drafting gate at
Waikaia Plains.

Author: GORDON
Quote:
Yards are full, race
is full, gates are
latched .. except
the little one by
the drafting gates!

In larger sets of
yards one of more of
these drafting pens
communicate via a
gate ...

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
This drafting race
divides sheep into
the separate lots
required, and these
are then handled by
the drafting pens,
check pens and
holding yards, which
should correspond in
size to the
receiving yards.

Author: RIDDOLL
Quote:
There should be as
many drafting pens
as there are ways of
drafting. The check
pens should be
adjacent to the
drafting pens and
should equal them in
number.

Author: MULGAN
Quote:
There were stables
and ... a huge
wool-shed and
drafting pens.

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
This drafting race
divides sheep into
the separate lots
required, and these
are then handled by
the drafting pens,
check pens, and
holding yards, which
should correspond in
size to the
receiving yards.

Author: WALLIS
Quote:
There a baler was a
brochure number, a
header a price.
Somewhere outside
... there were
salesmen talking to
farmers, ... sitting
astride the drafting
pens discussing dips
and shearing
machines and drug
dispensers ...

Author: Geary
Quote:
A drench salesman
had sworn he'd once
seen Craven break
alkathene across the
rear of one
hyena-looking
huntaway that
wouldn't stay out of
the drafting race.

Author: W.H.S. ROBERTS
Quote:
At Macfarlane's the
men saddled fresh
horses and rode in
some cattle which we
had a great bother
to yard, as
everything was new
... The yard was
divided into three -
one large and two
small - but as there
was no crush pen, or
drafting race, we
had to head rope
those requiring
branding.
Notes: 1856 Dec 18 W.H.S. Roberts diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 43-44

Author: PERRY
Quote:
[The sheep yards]
should consist of
receiving yards at
each end, forcing
pen, and drafting
race.

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
This drafting race
divides sheep into
the separate lots
required, and these
are then handled by
the drafting pens,
check pens, and
holding yards, which
should correspond in
size to thereceiving
yards.

Author: SCRYMGEOUR
Quote:
`Teviot' had a
magnificent stone
and steel woolshed
[built 1880] ...
with two complete
drafting races, much
wool storage room,
two ancient screw
presses, and stands
for 26 blade
shearers, for this
was the era before
the Ferrier
Woolpress, ...

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
DRAFTING: The main
feature of
sheepyards is the
drafting race. This
race, perhaps eight
feet in length, is
only wide enough for
sheep to pass
through in single
file; at the end of
the race are two
swinging gates which
can be manipulated
to turn the sheep
into different
yards, and so
separate them into
different `lines' or
mobs.

At times foot-rot
troughs are at the
bottom of the
drafting race and
covered over.. when
not in use.

Author: PERRY
Quote:
They [sheep yards]
should consist of
receiving yards at
each end, forcing
pen and drafting
race.

Now begins the long
struggle at the
drafting race.

All the drafting
races were in yards
that have seen many
years service.

Those modifications
[to a farm bike]
include carriers
back and front, and
holders for
shepherd's crooks, a
drafting stick etc.

Hours spent in the
drafting yards mean,
often, unpolished
floors.

These two pictures
show two completely
different approaches
to the problem of
providing cattle
drafting yards.

Source: Big Country of the North Island
Author: NEWTON
Quote:
The drafting yards
on the ground floor
are all of dressed
timber.

Author: MACINTOSH
Quote:
.. when a difficult
muster is completed
and the sheep are in
the drafting yards
and holding paddock
...

Author: FERNADEZ
Quote:
Barbara and Kathie
dawdled across the
horse paddock by the
homestead heading
for the dusty,
noisy, drafting
yards.

Author: ALLOM
Quote:
`I will conclude
this part of the
subject with a few
words about
stockyards. They are
generally made of
stout posts and
rails; the corner
posts ought to be
much stronger than
the rest, as they
often have to bear
the weight of a
heavy bullock in
branding and other
operations. The yard
is generally divided
into three portions
- viz., a large yard
for the whole herd,
a drafting yard, and
a milking yard, at
one end of which is
placed the milking
shed, cow bails, and
calf house, the
whole being so
arranged that a calf
can be let out to
suck its mother on
one side while she
is being milked on
the other.'

Drafting yard and
cow bails.

Author: PAUL
Quote:
... use a
hurdle-yard for
shearing ... have
your permanent
drafting-yard
elsewhere.

Author: J.G.WILSON
Quote:
Donald and Mick went
over to the Bush at
Sandy's to cut posts
for the Drafting
yard.
Notes: 1874 Apr 29 J.G.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 186

Author: T.C. KIERNAN
Quote:
T.C.K. went to
Tutira to mend gates
at drafting-yard.
Notes: 1879 Feb 19 T.C. Kiernan Diary in 1921 Guthrie Smith Tutira 126

Author: PERRY
Quote:
Sheep Yards. - The
erection of drafting
yards is one of the
first improvements
to be attended to by
the young sheep
farmer.

Author: DARE
Quote:
We had to move the
whole lot to the
drafting yards.

drafting-yard A yard
or enclosure for
drafting cattle.

drafting-yard n.
yard divided into
compartments for
drafting sheep or
cattle into groups.

Author: FERNANDEZ
Quote:
Barbara ... dawdled
across the horse
paddock by the
homestead heading
for the dusty,
noisy, drafting
yards.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote:
Drag the chain. To
be at the rear in a
race or in a game
(of, e.g.,
cribbage): New
Zealand: C. 20.
Niall Alexander,
letter of Oct. 22,
1939, `The
ploughman's term to
designate his slow
horse that does not
keep its chains
tight'.

Author: PROF. W. CAMERON
Quote:
A trampers' term
applied to those who
go very slowly
(uphill).

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote:
Drag. v. ... -3.
v.i. and v.t., to
take a portion of
the stakes in a
gambling game as a
reserve for future
play: Australian and
New Zealand: C. 20.

See him [sc. a
shepherd] drag a
gully full of tomos
and patches of scrub
and guarantee ...
you wouldn't find
one straggler.

Author: Capt. Joy
Quote:
Second Mate had his
boat robbed ... of a
bottle of rum, it
being customary to
carry it here so
that in case of a
hard drag to give it
to the boats crew
...
Notes: 1836 May 6 Capt. Joy Mary Mitchell log in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 439

Source: Story of a NZ River, The
Author: MANDER
Quote: By day the whole bay vibrated with the whistle and screech of the circular saws, the tear of the break downs, the rasp of the drags, ... Ibid. 198 They watched the progress of the log from the booms up the skids to the side of the breakdown platform... Halved and quartered, it was then levered ... on to greased rollers and rushed towards the big circulars, which turned it into flitches. Then the small circulars, the drag, and the goose completed its metamorphosis into the regulation strips ...

According to a
well-known
Christchurch demon,
the slang of three
months in thieves'
argot is `a drag'.
`Critic' thought a
'tec was the `drag'
when he pinched 'em.

These tailings are
treated in berdans
with extra
quicksilver
andground up. The
berdans now in use
at the Thames ...
are generally five
feet in diameter ...
At one time a couple
of rotating balls
were considered
sufficient for the
amount of crushing
required; now, the
general practice is
to have a loose ball
as well as a
stationary one
attached to a
chain,and it is
called a drag ball;
this drag does more
work than a loose
ball ... for the
drag grinds the bowl
as much as the
tailings.

Author: CHINN
Quote:
A Drag Hunt Club was
formed. The quarry
in this type of hunt
was not live game,
but a scent was laid
down before hand by
a sack or sheepskin,
impregnated with
some strong smell
such as anise, being
dragged over the
course.'

Source: From the Beginning: chronicles of a county
Author: KERR
Quote:
Arthur Barker at
Winchester and W
Postlethwaite at
Raukapuka had packs
of beagles too, and
the type of hunting
indulged in then was
the 'drag-hunt' when
a bag doused with
aniseed was dragged
along the course to
be followed by the
hounds.

Source: From the Toss of a Coin
Author: HAYES
Quote:
Jasper Nicols was
one-time Master of
the Drag Hunt, which
was a picnic outing
for those who could
not ride but still
came in buggies to
watch.

A tearful Putaruru
Mongrel Mob leader
admitted in the
Napier High Court
yesterday that he
wastrying to `drag
off' another car
when his car smashed
head-on into an
oncoming station
wagon and killed a
man, his wife and
two of their three
children.

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
I think it's time we
dragged our hook,
Sam. It's about time
a man had a little
holiday. I can feel
the itchy feet
coming on.

Author: STACEY
Quote:
The creeks and
streams had not been
cleared for years,
and it was
backbreaking job
cutting the weeds
into manageable
sizes and pulling
them out to the bank
with a drag rake.

Drag the chain, to.
To be the slowest
shearer in a shed.

Author: BAKER
Quote:
From the New Zealand
shearing sheds came
those effective
expressions to drag
the chain and swing
the gate, phrases
applied to the
slowest and fastest
shearer in a shed
respectively.

Drag the chain,
to.-To be the
slowest shearer in a
shed.

Author: BAKER
Quote:
From the New Zealand
shearing sheds came
those effective
expressions to drag
the chain and swing
the gate, phrases
applied to the
slowest and the
fastest shearer in
the shed
respectively.

Drag the chain: To
be the slowest
shearer in the shed.

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Quote:
To drag the chain is
a shearer's term
meaning `to be a
slow worker'.

dragging the chain:
A shearer is said to
do this when he lags
behind the rest
because he is slow,
lazy or
inexperienced. The
origin is from
bullock driving
where it is said
that the rear
bullock attached by
a chain to the
wagon, `drags the
chain' if it slows
down.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
But stop dragging
the chain. Drink up
and have one on me.

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Quote: Stop dragging the chain supplies a need where the etiquette of drinking requires rapidconsumption of liquor: it means `hurry up with your drinks so that the next round can begin'. Ibid. 131 To drink more slowly than the group is `to drag the chain'.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
Shagging about like
an old moll at a
christening -
Dragging the chain -

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
Shagging about like
an old moll at a
christening -
Dragging the chain -

Author: McGILL
Quote:
dragging the chain
holding up a group's
activities, such as
a drinking school;
originally the
slowest shearer in
the shed; eg
`Larry's dragging
the chain again on
keeping his berm
mowed.' NZA.

There's old timers
we knew, and some
who shot throughA
hard case, drag the
chain, done a
bunk,As busy as a
blow fly, and
bugalugs - from the
boo-aiThe
rouseabout, as drunk
as a skunk.

Author: BAINES
Quote:
Cross-cut saws have
what is called a
peg-tooth and cut
both ways. It is a
great improvement to
sharpen every fifth
tooth, counting from
the centre to the
ends, as a drag
tooth, that is, a
tooth filed square
across and with a
considerable hook,
this arrangement
tends to keep the
cut clear of
sawdust.

... crosscuts known
as drag-tooth saws.
Notes: [ca1914] 1951 H.S. McCarroll The Days of the Kauri Bushmen [Radio Talk 2: TS]

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
Some of his best
days had been spent
working as a postal
assistant ... He had
been a spreader in
the mailroom and a
dragger on the
landing.

...fully 20 cars
start up and rumble
out of the parking
lot... The dragline
is in operation. The
convoy rolls south
down the motorway,
keeping in touch
with each other in
the thin traffic by
flashing their
hazard lights.

Dragon fruit:
Otherwise known as
pitaya and grown in
the Bay of Plenty,
this fruit is
usually exported but
you can find its
distinctive shape in
chic fruit and
vegetable shops.

Author: REISCHEK
Quote:
In spite of this
warning I climbed
down a steep bank to
the cave, but found
no bones, only a
beautiful group of
dragon-palms - a
rare coincidence.
The leaves of these
Dracaenae - called
by the Maoris
tohi-palms - possess
flexible fibres out
of which the natives
weave their
waterproof rain-mats
(pureke).

Source: Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
Author: FORSTER
Quote: We met with a great many Cabbage-palmtrees, [Cordyline australis] as they were commonly called by our Sailors, but upon Examination we found them to be a kind of Dragon tree (Dracaena Linn): for we met with the fruit and flowers of them. Ibid. May 13 2/277[?nikau???] ... an infinite variety of high trees & shrubbery [in Dusky Bay], among which theNew-Zeeland Dragon-tree (Dracaena antarctica) [ed. fn Cordyline australis] is very remarkable; (NB Our Sailors called them the Cabbage-palm, but it is different; though the middle most leaves may be eaten & taste almost like sweet fresh Almonds).

Author: FORSTER
Quote:
[??=nikau] These
trees, however, were
not the true
cabbage-palms, nor
did they belong at
all to the class of
palms, ... They were
properly speaking a
new species of
dragon-trees, with
broad leaves
(dracaena australis)
of which the central
shoot when quite
tender, tastes
something like an
almond's kernel,
with a little of the
flavour of cabbage.

Author: NICHOLAS
Quote: A species of Dragon-tree, the central shoot of which partook at once both of the flavour of cabbage and of an almond kernel. Ibid. 2/247 [=??nikau, though prob. Cordyline cabbage as Andersen says: Nicholas ref. to Forster 1/176 above] They [Cook's people] found here also ... a new species of dragon-tree, the central shoot of which partook at once both of the flavour of cabbage and of an almond kernel. [reference Forster 1/176]

Author: BIDWILL
Quote:
I here first saw the
great Dracophyllum;
it formed a small
tree about six
inches in diameter,
and twenty feet
high; it is one of
the most curious
plants in the world;
the leaves grow in
tufts at the ends of
the branches, just
as in the dragon
tree (Dracaena), and
are the same shape,
but in this species
they are elegantly
reflexed, like the
feathers of a
soldier's plume;
they are a foot long
and an inch broad at
the base.

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote:
Ti - sweet root of
the dragon-tree

Author: ANGAS
Quote: The tropical-looking dragon-trees (dracaena), called ti by the natives, and the karaka-tree, grow up the steep sides of the hills ... Ibid. 2/9 [ti] Onwards, through gently undulating fern-land, interspersed with bushes of phormium tenax and an occasional dragon-tree, we againfound belts of forest-land. Ibid. 2/28 A grove of dragon-trees (Ti).

Author: EARP
Quote:
.. the sides of the
[Wellington] hills
... are almost
tropical in their
character, from the
abundance of the ti,
or dragon trees,
with which they are
covered.

`When this name was
given the tree was
Dracoena australis.'
Notes: 1856 Jan Tancred Notes on Natural History Canterbury

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote: Cordyline belongs to the sub-family Dracoenoideae, and is therefore related to the dragon-trees.

Author: HARPER
Quote:
In places [in the
Otira district] a
stunted mountain
birch grows freely,
and a curious
Dracena, or dragon
tree, with a seed
that resembles a

red colour.

Quote: DRAGONET Foetorepus phasis (Callionymus phasis, Yerutius phasis) ... [285] They ... give off a very strong smell when captured, giving rise to an alternative common name of stinkfish.

[index to common
names 283-293]
dragonet 1989

Tom Pollard and the
members of his
company became the
guests of the
officers of the
contingent, driving
out to the camp in
drags.

This faulting has
effected a
considerable `drag'
of the vein to the

north-north-east
fault effects a

Buhman further casts
doubt on the
so-called
`dragstone,'
theposition of which
influenced
prospecting for the
lost portion, and
doubts its value as
an index to the
direction of
movement; he
mentions that drag
quartz diminished
when followed up the
fault-plane and
along the strike of
the fault, whereas
the amount of
dragstone should

Author: ROY GILBERD

[The fibres of wood
in a tree just about
to fall] do not part
all in one plane and
`stringers' or
`drawers' are drawn
out of the barrel,
sometimes several
feet long. Sometimes
men on contract,
trying to save
timber, place their
saw-cut too low and
some of the
wood-fibres break
off up in the
barrel. These are
`stringers' while
they are breaking,
and `slivers' or
`drawers' when they
are left upright in
the sloven.

Author: REED
Quote: A `draw' was a serious defect, but was not due to any fault in the living tree. When a tree fell before it was quite severed, it sometimes, in the act of falling, wrenched or `drew' out a portion of the butt, leaving great jagged, fang-like splinters adhering to the stump. The damage was, of course, always to the heart wood ... [Ibid. 156 [Edward Thompson] ... very often, before the saw got within a foot or so of the front scarf, the tree would start to fall gradually, and the uncut timber between the saw and the front scarf would have to break, and seldom cleanly; the heart, being more brittle than the sap, would break here and there, several feet above where thesawcut would have been standing straight. As the tree fell, these pieces, still attached to the stump, would draw out of the tree, and being almost heart-wood constituted the chief defect we call `draws'.

The word "dregs" refers to the drippings from the taps in a bar and to the overflow from the glasses as they are filled. These dregs are sometimes called "swill".. or "slops". When they are mixed with beer for sale the resultant liquid is colloquially known as "Wompo". The term has been in use among barmen for as long as one experienced licensee could recollect - from twenty to thirty years.., and it is known to the man in the street. Ibid. 115 The resultant "Wompo" was then served to the public.
