unsound.' - `He must
be: he organised
this year's drinking
horn.'

[The stories] are
inspiring, too,
though Sefton spares
readers the slavish
drippery that runs
through many New
Zealand sports
books.

Source: Reminiscences of a New Chum in Otago
Author: SCOTT
Quote:
.. instead of
sliding comfortably
down a shoot [sic]
into their sixty
seconds' bathe and
walking leisurely
upstairs to the
'dripping pen' the
sheep were jammed
into a small yard.

Author: ANDERSON
Quote:
We were on a hare
drive one day ...

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
Ash Faigan also
mentioned the
'drives' which were
once a method of
rabbit destruction.
One such drive in
the Waipiata
district yielded
over 4,000.

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
This results in the
wool often pulling
the skin out, which
makes it sometimes
difficult to 'drive'
with a full comb
without marking the
sheep.

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
... the Corriedale
produces a big
weight of wool, and
yet has the tender,
loose skin of the
Merino. This results
in the wool often
pulling the skin
out, which makes it
sometimes difficult
to `drive' with a
full comb without
marking the sheep.

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Quote:
Harry had just given
the last cut of the
axe to a big rimu,
which, after a far
premonitory cracks
as it began to move,
fell, driving before
it in its line of
fall a dozen or so
of the smaller
trees, which had
been `scarfed' or
cut partly through
in readiness, and
skilfully, so that
each, when struck,
might again in its
turn strike and
bring down another.
The noise of a fall
or drive of this
kind is like thunder
- loud, prolonged,
reverberating.

Author: KOEBEL
Quote:
[drive n and v.t.
described as
scarfing trees in a
line (on a rise),
then falling the
back one to push the
rest down in a
line.]

Author: CARR
Quote:
Even the most
experienced men
sometimes get caught
by a falling tree or
branch, or clearing
a `drive' that has
missed.

Author: KENWAY
Quote:
Selecting a certain
group of trees he
will `belly scarf'
and `back scarf' the
lot ... If this
`drive' as it is
termed, has been
well-managed the
whole lot will came
down together.

Author: LEVY
Quote:
... from early
morning till dark
the axe would
resound and the
crash of falling
trees, or drive of
trees, would be the
only sound ...

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
Jack learned about
scarfing, backing,
limbing, ... toms,
strops, drives,
triggers, ...

Author: LYON
Quote:
The bushmen
developed an expert
knowledge of
driving, or
directing one tree
against another, or
a body of trees,
which swept a great
weight in one
irresistible drive
of crashing and
thunderous timber.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
He had seen as many
as twenty-four men
in a single
[professional
bushfalling] gang
and they worked
`drives' of up to
five acres and more
[in the King
Country].

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
It was quite a
common practice for
experienced bushmen,
to have a `drive'.
If you are chopping
up a `face' and
there is a large
tree behind you
further up the face,
you select that as
the `key'. To save
time ... you do not
waste time by
chopping down each
tree individually,
but just `scarf' and
partly chop each
tree. When all is
ready and you have
worked back to the
key, you scarf it
verycarefully. ...
If everything goes
according to plan it
will `drive' the one
below, which will in
turn drive the next,
and so on ...

Author: WILSON
Quote:
A `drive' was in
progress; as the men
do the
underscrubbing they
note the large trees
and their distance
from each other.
They scarf each one
so that it will fall
on the next. Then,
after all the
smaller timber has
been brought down,
they fell the first
tree which falls on
the second and so
starts a whole
sequence of crashes.
The line need not be
straight. More
often, it zig-zags
from right to left.
Bushmen can do
wonders by means of
an ingenious drive.

[quartz] Taking the
claims as they came,
the first ...
consisted of a drive
of about a hundred
feet into a
prominent looking
`spur'.

If he [sc. a mining
manager] goes out in
a buggy for a day
hecharges it to the
company as `putting
in a fresh drive'

Author: BAINES
Quote:
Our reef, or leader,
measuring only four
inches in thickness,
a drive for a
considerable
distance following
the course of the
gold-bearing quartz
had to be carried
out, ...

Author: MONEY
Quote:
... the work was
both difficult and
dangerous, being a
drive or tunnel made
into the side of the
hill, ... blasting
the rocks that were
too big ...

Author: THATCHER
Quote: In London the swells in the park drive all round, But the diggers drive here with a pick underground; And the props that they use, surely everyone knows Ain't the same used in London for hanging up clothes. The women use fans* there, the men use them here, Though to cockneys that statement may sound very queer, And the fellows that frequently hang round hotels, Out here are called loafers, at home are called swells. Ibid. [p 89 fn] * A fan is a machine for pumping air down the shafts.

Author: LAPHAM
Quote:
There was a deserted
`drive' up on the
spur.

But Steel had
already disappeared
down the winze. ...
The whole roof of
the drive fell in.

Mr Coombs took me
down [the Waihi
mine] and ... we
went into every
drive 900 ft. down.

Author: PURNELL
Quote:
Then rushed the
[coal] miners from
their hollow
`drives'.

Author: HEINZ
Quote:
Drive: A horizontal
tunnel.

Author: DEVANNY
Quote:
(coalmining) ...
drives were broken
off at right angles
to [the dip heading]
at distances of two
chains apart ; thus
forming pillars on
either side of the
dip, two chains
square. These drives
were called main
levels. The bords
were driven about
two chains off the
dip, and the
`stenton' would be
driven from the
lower level to the
one above.

Author: BLYTH
Quote:
Drive: A horizontal
drift, or tunnel, in
a mine.

Author: MAY
Quote:
DRIVE: a horizontal
excavation. As a
verb (`driving') to
make a horizontal
excavation. `Drive'
and `tunnel' were
used
interchangeably, but
properly one
tunnelled into a
lead or reef and
then commenced to
`drive' along it.

Author: McCARTHY
Quote:
Paddy made bigger
money than most of
the miners, taking
on contracting work
in driving the
levels, or drives.
These drives were
the roadways where
we trucked the stone
from the stopes. To
get down to drive
each level ...

Author: McARA
Quote:
Drift or drive: A
tunnel usually
driven parallel with
the reef. a passage
or tunnel excavated
horizontally (cf v4)

Author: NOLAN
Quote:
Drive: same as drift
(above). Incorrect,
but sanctioned by
common usage.

Rained all last
night, ... made a
shorter drive to the
[Arowhenua] bush.

... I finde I shall
clear about
73[pounds] out of my
two drives
50[pounds] out of Mr
Harris and the rest
from Mr Acland.

Went down several
more feet with our
pit. One of the
digers [sic] helped
us and he came to
the conclusion we
should have to
paddock it which is
to work it like a
quarry, large at the
top instead of
driveing levells
[sic]. This man and
his mates afterwards
worked it in this
way ... Theygot
colour.

The washdirt was
`paddocked' or
`driven' out, and
carried or carted to
where there was
water.

Author: EVANS
Quote:
Immediately north of
the [Waikaka]
township a rich
layer in the
fault-involved older
quartz drifts, ...
was worked from the
surface ... This
layer is locally
known as the `back
lead'. On or near it
a shaft was sunk ...
but was not utilised
for driving-out. ...
Somewhere about 1880
... others drove an
inclined drift from
point to the
southward of the
back lead for a
distance of 254 feet
... Then they drove
horizontally for a
short distance and
intersected an
auriferous ... layer
of quartz wash,
about 10 feet wide,
known as the `front
lead'.
Notes: 1914 P.G. Morgan report Geological Survey Branch 147 in 1962 Evans Waikaka Saga 4

Quote:
No. 3 adit ... has
been driven 750 ft.
in a formation of
crushed and sheeted
country traversed by
numerous stringers
and veinlets of
quartz.

Author: MAY
Quote:
DRIVE: a horizontal
excavation. As a
verb (`driving') to
make a horizontal
excavation. `Drive'
and `tunnel' were
used
interchangeably, but
properly one
tunnelled into a
lead or reef and
then commenced to
`drive' along it.

Messrs. Nelson
Brothers, of the
meat-freezing works
at Tomoana, kindly
offered to receive
and paddock any
black lambs
forwarded ... to
their works until
such time as a drive
of black lambsshould
be collected
together.

Axe-men's contest
[showing chops] ?
the stroke which
leads up to severing
the block.

Source: Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker
Author: THOMSON
Quote:
Charlie, ever on the
lookout for making
fun of me, said that
it was just as well
that Dick and he
were the only two in
the vicinity, as a
stranger would think
I was a deer barking
and let drive at me
from the bush, ...

Where [? When] there
are sufficient logs
for a "drive," the
dam is "tripped"
during a"fresh" or
flood.

By means fair and
foul the logs were
assembled in creeks
to await a big flood
called a 'drive'
that would float
them out to tidal
water.

Author: BAINES
Quote:
When all was
completed I had one
hundred logs rolled
into the stream
below, and thirty
above the dam. I
then fixed upon a
day and an hour to
have a `drive,' and
mustered all the men
I could.

Often it is
necessary to
construct costly
dams to impound the
water in the upper
parts of the creek,
in order that it may
be suddenly
liberated ... so
that the entire
assemblage [332] of
[kauri] logs may be
`driven' to the
booms. In dry
seasons the logs may
remain in the bed of
the creek for
months, and,
occasionally, after
a successful
`drive', the harvest
of logs is carried
out tosea and lost,
through the booms
breaking from the
immense pressure
behind them.

Author: KIRK
Quote:
... [the booms]
often enclose an
area of several
acres, which after a
successful `drive,'
is crowded with
thousands of logs.

[The dam] looked
well for a good
`drive,' and the
boss gave the word
to `trip' it and let
her go as soon as
the logs were
straightened up.

During a `drive' the
logs, driven by the
rush of the waters,
scour out the
bottoms of the
creeks, and create
artificial floods,
by which logs,
dragged to the
creeks, may be
transported.

Author: REED
Quote:
Other men, if
available, would at
the same time be
preparing the creek
bed for the `drive.'

The release of water
and logs by tripping
the dam was known as
a drive.

Drive : A horizontal
tunnel on the reef

Author: BAINES
Quote:
The `stand of kauri'
I had acquired
...was estimated to
contain upwards of a
million feet of
timber, capable of
being `driven out'
by placing a
flood-dam in a
suitable position
... too great a body
of water filling the
creek at one time
for a `drive.'

The only other
practical method I
can propose for the
preservation of
timber is to `drive'
the logs down to
deep-water at once.

Author: KIRK
Quote:
... the sluices of
the dams are opened,
and the logs, which
are often piled high
in the bed of the
stream, are `driven'
to the booms by the
volume of water
suddenly liberated.

Often it is
necessary to
construct costly
dams to impound the
water in the upper
parts of the creek,
in order that it may
be suddenly
liberated ... so
that the entire
assemblage [332] of
[kauri] logs may be
`driven' to the
booms. In dry
seasons the logs may
remain in the bed of
the creek for
months, and,
occasionally, after
a successful
`drive', the harvest
of logs is carried
out to sea and lost,
through the booms
breaking from the
immense pressure
behind them.

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote:
Here [the kauri
logs] lie until a
`fresh' drives them
down the creek or
harbour where the
`boom' lies waiting.

The logs were
transported to the
mill in the case of
the Waitanui by a
wooden-railed
tramway; in the case
of the Tamaki they
were `driven.'

It was a great dam
and drove 10,000,000
feet of timber out.
Notes: [ca1914] 1951 H.S. McCarroll The Days of the Kauri Bushmen [Radio Talk 4: [TS]]

Author: RIDGEWAY
Quote:
The burning off
should be driven as
late in the season
as it is safe to do
so.

`Reached sheep about
two o'clock, -
rounded them up and
began driving at
once. Reached
ourproposed
camping-ground about
sundown.

Breakfast before
daylight, cutting
out till 4 o'clock
when we drove five
miles along the sea
shore, jamed [sic]
the cattle in a bite
and pitched our
tent, boiled some of
my cocoa

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
Sheep race before it
[sc. southerly
burster] as hard as
they can go
helter-skelter, ...
There is no shelter
on the plains, and,
unless stopped by
the shepherds, they
will drive from one
river to the next.

... I mention these
impediments more
particularly, to
shew the utter
impossibility of
ever driving stock
or taking a horse
coastwise to
Canterbury, ...

Source: Crusts: a settler's fare due south
Author: KENNAWAY
Quote: As a rule, to drive a mob of sheep for any distance, takes not less than four hands ... Ibid.It needs incessant care to prevent stragglers breaking away from the head and sides of the mob, and the rear of the flock, made up of the weaker sheep, requires an equally constant lookout. The horses are led or ridden, as the ground allows; ... but in driving through unknown country, the halts are made very much where the explorers find themselves at sundown.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
Drive: In very rough
bluffy country it is
sometimes possible
to muster, or
`drive,' deer into
some spot where they
will be cornered or
trapped, and a big
kill can be made.

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH
Quote:
Clyde [a Kelpie]
isn't an unqualified
success at `driving'
yet; but by the time
we have finished
shearing he will
know as much as the
next dog.

I should like to get
a drive or two
before going to the
diggins it would
give one more pocket
money.

[Mr Harris] asked me
to bring a mob of
sheep from
Moorhouses ... for
him, ... Have taken
the drive and leave
Mt. Peel on Thursday
morning.

Source: Crusts: a settler's fare due south
Author: KENNAWAY
Quote: The [sheep] drive ... continued with varying fortune for three weeks. ... We drove steadily by day, steering down [157] the plains due South, and camping at night as best we could; .. Ibid. 204 On the drive, or on the run, or in the yards,- ... they [sc cattle] just ... continuedwild ... and at shortest notice, dangerous.

Author: SCOTT
Quote:
There was a fair
muster of sheep in
the [sale-]yards so
we did not think we
should have much
trouble in getting a
drive.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
There were
sufficient [sheep]
to make a `drive'
out to the back.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
For some years he
was on the road for
[the Richards]
collecting cattle
they had purchased,
and was also on
drives to Appleby.

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Quote: Harry had just given the last cut of the axe to a big rimu, which, after a far premonitory cracks as it began to move, fell, driving before it in its line of fall a dozen or so of the smaller trees, which had been `scarfed' or cut partly through in readiness, and skilfully, so that each, when struck, might again in its turn strike and bring down another. The noise of a fall or drive of this kind is like thunder - loud, prolonged, reverberating. Ibid.. 94 Harry had planned a big drive with a combined rimu and rata ... had `scarfed' all the smaller trees in front of it down to the already felled bush, and expected, when it was brought down, that it would send to earth the whole of these, driving one upon another far beyond the reach of its own length ...

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
The three [15]
brothers spent the
first few weeks
clearing, learning
the art of chopping,
scarfing, driving
and working a face.

Author: McGILL
Quote: drive the pigs home to snore; in England the phrase is: 'drive the pigs to the market.'
Sunny, drive on section, with a babbling brook and mature trees. Ibid. 3 It has drive on with a double carport and extra parking.

You could be moving
into a brand new,
architecturally
designed home for a
very reasonable
price if you've got
your sights set on a
home that:*is on a
flat section * has
drive-on access and
garaging* is close
to the city and
beach.
Sunny, drive on section, with a babbling brook and mature trees. Ibid. 3 It has drive on with a double carport and extra parking.

In addition to these
factors, other
positive earnings
drivers include
lower churn rates
(the precentage of
residential
subscribers over the
last 12 mnonth
period who
terminated their
subscriptions), an
appreciating NZ
dollar.. increased
pay-per view revenue
and the recent
launch of its e-mail
and interactive
service.

One driver for
buying 3G is to make
sure you've got
insurance.

[They] believe that
Telstra-Saturn's
business drivers -
details of the
company's time, cost
and resources - were
added during the
group's
deliberations... The
terms of reference
included the
business drivers and
we accepted the
terms on that basis.

Author: ELWELL
Quote:
... drivers
[=drovers]

Drover: One who
drives stock for a
living. In
Canterbury they were
usually spoken of as
sheep- or
cattle-drivers until
about 1900.

Driver:A leather
strap on the handle
of a pair of shears,
which fits over the
back of the
shearer's hand. (C.)

Author: McLEOD
Quote:
The shearers buy
their shears from
the station and then
proceed to cut them
and bend them, and
embellish them with
`drivers,'
`knockers,'
`jockeys' and
`cockspurs' until
their makers would
hardly recognise
them.

driver ... NZ &
Austral. leather
strap on handle of
shears to prevent
the shearer's hand
from slipping on to
the blades.

Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Quote:
Driver. Leather or
lampwick strap on
the handle of a pair
of shears.

driver: A leather
strap on hand
shears. This fits
firmly round the
handle and over the
back of the
shearer's hand, thus
allowing more drive
to be given to a
blow while
preventing the hands
from slipping over
the blades.
Sometimes this is
also called the
`monkey'.

The driver takes the
trucks through the
mine races, and
deposits them in
lay-bys, places
similar to ...
railway sidings.
Here the trucks are
received by the
hangers-on, boys who
attach the trucks to
an endless rope.

Author: BAINES
Quote:
The former [sc a
natural fresh] is
not to be depended
upon, too great a
body of water
filling the creek at
a time for `a
driver', whilst at
another there would
hardly be any flood
at all.

Author: LYON
Quote:
Again, a tough old
rata or hinau often
had a tall pine
felled and lodged in
its branches, with
the result that the
weight of the driver
and the lower tree
were too much for
the supporting one,
and a few cautious
axe strokes
completed the job.

Author: GRADY
Quote:
Driver - The man who
drove a high-speed
launch type of
whale-chaser as used
by the Peranos in a
whale-hunt.

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
The shearers buy
their shears from
the station and then
proceed to cut them
and bend them and
embellish them with
'drivers',
'knockers',
'jockeys' and
'cockspurs' until
their makers would
hardly recognise
them.

A driver can be
fitted, using a
strip of leather or
lamp wick.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
driver: a strap,
usually of cotton
lampwick, bound on
to a pair of hand
shears to fit round
the back of the
hand.

Author: COULSON
Quote:
Some men attached a
leather flange known
as a 'driver' to the
handle to facilitate
cutting and ease the
swelling of wrists
from constant
movement.

You have been in
that district, about
the creeks where the
driving of the logs
takes place?

... the `driving' of
large kauri-logs in
the creeks by
`tripping' dams
during flood-time
... [98??] ...
Recently the
creek-beds have been
thoroughly scoured
... owing to the
`driving' of kauri
timber by lumbermen.

Stripped of their
branches they could
be floated down the
driving creeks with
the ordinary logs,
and if `broken down'
or cut into suitable
boards for
wainscoting and
furniture, would be
highly appreciated
for their striking
beauty.

My son ... took a
leading spur on the
right bank of what
had been a
driving-creek for
kauri logs ...

Author: REED
Quote:
In a steep driving
creek, a branch of
the Kapowai, the
sub-contractor had
built a dam in very
much of a hurry.

When the natural
supply of water is
not sufficient to
float these [logs]
they are forced
along by
driving-dams or
hauled out of the
bush, either by
bullocks or
steam-engines.

We waded downstream,
passing the
confluences with
Pukearuhe Stream and
Stoney Creek, which,
with Spragg Stream,
probably had driving
dams in the old
days.

Inventive methods of
transportation were
devised to get logs
to the mills. One of
the most ingenious
involved the use of
timber dams, better
known as driving
dams... When enough
water had built up,
the dam would be
tripped and the logs
carried down the
stream to the
sawmill on the
resulting flood.

A driving dog is a
heading dog, and
therefore he should
always look after
the lead of the
sheep, the tail
usually looks after
itself.

Driving : The term
used to describe the
process of
tunnelling.

Author: EVANS
Quote:
Immediately north of
the [Waikaka]
township a rich
layer in the
fault-involved older
quartz drifts, ...
was worked from the
surface ... This
layer is locally
known as the `back
lead'. On or near it
a shaft was sunk ...
but was not utilised
for driving-out.
Notes: 1914 P.G. Morgan report Geological Survey Branch 147 in 1962 Evans Waikaka Saga 4

Author: McARA
Quote:
The term driving
generally referred
to tunnelling in any
direction but in
some circumstances,
where reefs were
present, it meant
tunnelling along the
line of the reef or
parallel to it. The
term drifting was
used more
specifically for
driving on a reef,
while the term
crosscutting
referred
totunnelling across
the reef up to an
angle of say
forty-five degrees;
however it was
common to talk of
`driving a
crosscut'.

Author: EDMUND BOWLER
Quote:
Hard work today
driving (droving)
owing to long grass.
[The `droving' is
Mayhew's insertion]
Notes: 1858 Jan 1 Edmund Bowler's Diary in 1949 Mayhew Tuapeka 12

Quote:
I wanted a [?]
driving sheep, but
he would not agree
to that.

Pattison and I have
the driving of 1500
Wethers from this
run to town ... and
I have the driving
of a mob down and
back ... in a few
weeks I hope.

... I had not time
to call on Tripp ...
so he has given his
driving to
O'Callaghan, a
stranger instead of
me.

Author: LEVY
Quote:
Next, the forest
trees up to
approximately 30 in.
in diameter were
felled by a system
of driving, the
trees being notched
on the upper and
lower side of the
drive, which
commenced at the top
of the slope and
proceeded downwards.

Author: LYON
Quote:
The bushmen
developed an expert
knowledge of
driving, or
directing one tree
against another, or
a body of trees,
which swept a great
weight in one
irresistible drive
of crashing and
thunderous timber.

Wellington's African
youth experience
frequent
discrimination -
including being
picked on by police
for "driving while
black", a study has
found. ... Some
reported being
frequently pulled
over by police for
no particular
reason, dubbed the
"DWB" or "driving
while black"
phenomenon, the
students found.

Source: Report on Geol. of SW Nelson
Author: McKAY
Quote:
Gold was got at the
furthest
depthreached, but

The words flew, and

government
departments. A
`Queen Street
farmer' was a city

land or stock for
tax-fiddle reasons.
`Skite' and `drongo'
were terms ofabuse.
A `cow-cockie' was a
dairy farmer and
inferior for some
reason to a
`runholder'
concerned only with
sheep. A `piker' was
a faint-hearted
person who gave up
the fight too soon,
...

and she's about to

... A non-New
Zealander will

friend is
communicating to me

a slow-witted,

of diminutive

is soon to give
birth.

know-all. `What do

babies, mate?' asked
Nuts.

Quote: She does catering, he said. And she sells it. You know what I mean, Dave - sly grog. One time when the police raided her she was doing the washing, Johnny said. And they reckoned they'd got her this time, because they'd found out a dropper had been through the town just a few nights before on his lorry. So they reckoned she'd be well stocked up. a horse at a vantage
point quietly
watching was
happening ahead.
Generally this would
be the 'drove boss.'

Counsel: `You drive
for a living?'
Witness: `No, I'm a
drover.' Counsel:
`Well, you drive
sheep for a living?'
Witness: `No; I
drove.' Counsel: `Do
you mean you used to
drive?' Witness:`No,
I drove now.'
Counsel: `H'mph!
What does your
brother do?'
Witness: `He's got a
timber contract.'
Counsel: `Oh, he's a
bush faller.'
Witness: `He's a
bush feller.'

drove v.t. to drive

see cit. drover.

Author: HOCHSTETTER
Quote:
The conglomerates
accumulated on the
slopes of the
mountains are the
proper field for the
"dry diggings",
while from the
gravel and sand
streams the gold is
obtained by "wet
diggings".

Author: HOCHSTETTER & PETERMAN
Quote:
By the gradual
wearing away of
these rocks ...
large masses of
debris have been
formed, and nature
itself has executed
an operation of
gold-washing, by
collecting the
heavier particles
and depositing them
in the gullies of
streams, or in the
conglomerates
covering the slopes
of the hills. There
are, therefore, two
principal
descriptions of
diggings; either
`river diggings', in
the beds of streams,
or `dry diggings',
in the conglomerate
and gravel
accumulated on the
slopes of the
mountains.

.. increasing
lambing percentage
by using recommended
teachniques such as
culling dry-dry and
wet-dry ewes and
shearing two-tooth
before tupping.

Dry dry ewes
amounted to about
four per cent, which
is nothing much.

Last season they
recorded 7.2% ewe
deaths over winter
and lambing, wet
dries were 7.8% dry
dry 1.7% and 15%
lamb deaths.

Author: KERR
Quote:
'Get the dry dries,
the wet dries and
the late wets' ..
When Nimmo came by
me, I asked him to
translate. The first
were fat barren ewes
destined for harder
territory, the
second were those
who lost their lambs
destined for harder
territory, and then
he too was gone, but
I figured 'late
wets' were late
lambers who'd want a
wee spell before
their lambs were
docked.

The account of the
Gully which he gives
is, that fair
prospects have been
found there, and his
opinion is that a
party can make an
ounce a man, as the
sinking is very
shallow, and the
working dry.

early days of its
history the Corbans
winery was located
in a 'dry'
electorate; the
small white building
in the background,
situated across the
railway lines in a
'wet' area was used

depot.

Mr Halford remembers
when there was a
post office, six
churches, three
hotels, three
garages, two
grocers, two
tearooms,
blacksmiths and
wheelwrights, a
bakery, bank,
drapery, hardware,
watchmaker and a
town hall, where the
ladies smuggled in
liquor to the dances
under their wide
skirts in the days
when the district
was "dry".

This is a "dry" town
with no licensed
hotels.

John says they
considered turning
it into a restaurant
because it is so far
up the hill it is
just outside the
Tawa boundary - and
therefore out of the
"dry" liquor area.
Tawa was a dry area
until it went wet
following the
election.

The hotel was closed
when the district
went "dry" in 1906,
the bar reopening
for business in
1998.
Paeroa is "dry".

From that date
[1906] the town was
legally "dry".

holidays.

The milk sugar
should be got rid of
as quickly as
possible when time
came for drying the
cow off and this was
best accomplished by
completing the
drying-off in the
minimum time.
Treating the subject
at length, Mr Wood
said that a cow
should not be 'dried
off' as was commonly
understood and
practised, but
should be left alone
and allowed to do so
naturally.

Quote:
As in most other
companies [dairy

Drying off cows
early does not

Quote:
If the trend reveals

dry-off thinner cows
or take other

The cows were being

It is generally

The Torlesse range
within its

Quote:

October arrived and

and any wethers that

The first round of

Author: McPHERSON
Quote:
Transecting the
Transantarctic
Mountains west of
McMurdo Sound are
three ice and
snow-free valleys
collectively called
the Dry Valleys. The
valleys extend from
the 2,750 m Polar
Plateau in the west
to within a short
distance of the sea.
Along with some
smaller subsidiary
valleys the system
constitutes the
largest ice-free
area in Antarctica,
a total of
approximately 4,000
square km.

Author: McPHERSON
Quote:
The Dry Valley
Region is a
geologist's paradise
because of the
excellent exposure
of rock, without
grass, trees, soil
or snow, to hide it.

Throughout the
summer Vanda Station
proved its value as
a staging station
for parties
operating within the
Dry Valley region...
Apart from making
measurements
throughout the year
of the climate of
this unique "Dry
Valley" area and of
the "hot" lake near
the station, the
wintering-over party
also carry out upper
atmosphere physics
and earthquake
observations in
conjunction with
Scott Base.

Author: KNIGHT
Quote:
Frighteningly, as
this book was going
to press, newspapers
in New Zealand
reported a
significant rise in
Lake Vanda, in the
Dry Valley region of
the Ross Dependency.

There are three main
Dry Valleys, the
Victoria Valley in
the north, the
Taylor Valley in the
south and the Wright
Valley in the west.
Together these three
valley systems
expose 4000 km2 of
moraines, sediments
and rocks - an oasis
on the edge of the
ice sheet.

The Dry Valleys were
originally
discovered in 1903
by Scott, Evans and
Lashly and since the
rediscovery by
geologists Peter
Webb and Barrie
McKelvey in 1957,
the work of summer
field parties,
including
geologists, chemists
and physicists, led
to the decision to
winter at Vanda
Station.

dry vote: See
`declare them wet'.

The place was
stuffed with diners
of all stripes, from
the suits to the
denim brigade to
women in polar
fleeces accompanied
by gents in
drizabones and
shooting caps.

We watched as Ra, in
a dry's-a-bone
raincoat herded the
great unwashed from
the door, instructed
them to get a bit of
tucker on board and
fly right before
attempting to breast
the tape of the pub
door.

Clarke's drizabone
delivery is perfect
for the task.

The All Blacks even
export the colonial
Drizabone look.

Source: From the Top of a Hill
Author: GASCOIGNE

Author: BREMNER
Quote:
A description of an
unidentified
sheepstation in 1881
recorded that a
twenty-two man gang
... put through [the
sheep-wash] 1250
sheep in a ... day.
The `yarder-up' kept
the pen nearest the
wash full of sheep.
Two
`dry-chuckers-in'
forced sheep through
a swing door where
they fell four feet
into a 20-foot
wooden trough full
of hot soapy water.
... The trough was
divided into four
partitions with a
`crutcher' at each.
Four times each
sheep was soaped,
its back scrubbed
with a crutch. ...
At the end of the
trough three
`wet-chuckers-in'
hauled frightened
sheep out and sent
them down three
slides to the
cold-water rinsing
wells. Each well had
two spouts of cold
water and four hands
called `spouters'
who tilted the
sheep, parting the
wool

The objects of dry
cow therapy are 1)
to eliminate
existing infections
of the udder 2) to
prevent new
infections during
the dry period. Dry
cow therapy helps
protect the cow
against these new
infections because
antibiotics are
present in the udder
for many weeks.

A warning against
farmers expecting
100 per cent results
from dry cow therapy
can be a valuable
tool against
mastitis. The
Wallaceville
researchers said
that dry cow therapy
was unable to
eliminate all
infections or
prevent reinfection
or new infection
during the dry
period.

Dairyfarmers should
note those cows
affected and
consider greater use
of dry-cow therapy
at drying-off.

The way dry-cow
therapy is used is
critical to success
.. Do not milk the
cows the last time
they are brought to
the shed, but give
them dry-cow
therapy.

Dry cow therapy
should be done
immediately after a
cow's last milking.

The cell count
average is low, all
cows will be dry by
sale day and will
have been dry cow
therapy treated.
[dry cow therapy]

Author: SUTHERLAND & TAYLOR
Quote:

to help pack the

...

for growth on our
bodies.

a bellows to blow
the dross away.

Author: BROOKING
Quote:
Much of the credit

He cites the example

The man who
developed the
Drysdale sheep
breed, Dr Francis
William Dry has died
in Palmerston North.
He was [87 years
old.] Dr Dye was
born in Driffield,
Yorkshire, and
educated at
Bridlington School
and Leeds University
from which he
graduated in 1925 as
a Doctor of Science.
He came to New
Zealand in 1929 to
be a lecturer at the
newly-founded Massey
Agricultural
College. Shortly
after his arrival Dr
Dry discovered a ram
lamb in a flock near
Palmerston North
which had an
extremely hairy
fleece due to an
abundance of
halo-hairs. Dr Dry's
successful efforts
to isolate the gene
in Romney led to the
development of the
Drysdale. Dr Dry
devoted nearly 40
years studying the
genetic makeup of
the fleece of the
sheep and published
many papers. He
retired from Massey
University in 1956
as Professor of
Animal Genetics but
continued his
interest in the
Drysdale till his
death.

Drysdale n. NZ breed
of sheep developed
from Romneys and
Cheviots yielding
wool which when
blended with
crossbred wool is
suitable for carpet
making. [F.W. Dry,
agricultural
scientist]

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Marbles had a
language of its own.
There were names for
the marbles, the
games, and all the
various aspects of
the play. There were
terms for marbles
such as `taw' or
`shooter', referring
to the marbles used
to fire with;
`dubs', `dates',
`stakes', `dukes',
or `changers',
referring to the
marbles put down to
be fired at. [175]
Here is Little Ring
as played in
Waitara, Taranaki,
in 1899: A team
would consist of six
to eight boys [order
of shooting
determined] ... An
oval ring was
decribed in the
earth by means of a
stick, and each
player would `dub
in' one marble ... A
line was drawn some
six or eight feet
away, as the firing
line, and the first
player sang out
`Fire!' as he fired
the first shot.]

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
It is important to
distinguish these
`Action-Terms' of
marbles from the
innumerable merely
descriptive marble
terms which have no
effect on the course
of the action -
terms such asRinger,
In, Smug, Dead
Stick, Skun,
Skinned, Sported
off, Scat, Cannons,
Dubs, Kills, Funs,
Keeps, Pink.

parrots, and
parroquets.

The River `Wiiaw' is
very spacious in
places, ... and
abounds in fish,
eels and wild-ducks
of 3 or 4 different
kinds.

I found [round
Wellington] Teal,
common Wild Duck,
the paradise Duck, a
variety of the
Grebe, a kind of
Water Hen the proper
name of which I do
not know.

We scarcely took a
step that did not
delight us; the soil
good, the banks of
the [Waipa] river
high, interspersed
with woods of
kahikatea. ... Here
the banks of the
river were covered
with wild-ducks.
Notes: 1841 Jan 4 Report of George Clarke, Protector of Aborigines in GBPP 1842 (No.569) 98

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:
These (wild ducks of
different sorts) are
principally the
black, the grey, the
blue-winged, and the
paradise duck, or
`pa tangi tangi', as
it is called by the
natives. The last is
nearly as large as a
goose, and of
beautiful plumage

Wild ducks, called
`Paradise Ducks',
nearly as large as a
Goose, splendid
eating.

Author: POWER
Quote:
A few curlews,
whale-birds,
sand-pipers, and
wild ducks frequent
the coast and river
swamps, but are
generally fishy, and
unfit for the table.

[The Waikato] runs
through ... deep
fern fringed with
raupo (a bullrush)
...[sic] and the
magnificent toi-toi,
a gigantic grass
whose flower stalk
is from 8 to 12 feet
and has an exquisite
feather of two feet
long playing in
every air. This
grass is ... with
the phormium tenax
the most remarkable
of the open country
vegetable products.
... You see many
nativedwellings &
many canoes for they
are a most
locomotive people,
few as ignorant of
all but their own
kainga as our
British Hodge. There
are troops of wild
ducks & shags, some
hawks of large size,
bitterns & smaller
waterfowl unknown to
me.

Author: BARKER
Quote:
I don't think a
minute passed
without a brace of
wild ducks flying
past, - grey, blue,
and Paradise.

Author: THOMSON
Quote:
Several kinds of
birds are indigenous
to the woods and
waters; among them
the oyster-catcher,
bittern, kingfisher,
cormorant, quail,
wild-duck, mocking
or [16] parson bird,
parrots, parroquets,
woodhen, pigeon,
etc. (the [sic]
gigantic Moa bird is
believed to be now
quite extinct).

Author: HAR T
Quote:
At the back ... was
a large raupo swamp,
which was a rare
resort for wild
ducks and pukaki.

Author: HOCHSTETTER
Quote: The Sultan-hen of brilliant plumage (Porphyris melanotus) [sic], or the Pukeko of the natives; the New Zealand bittern or Matuku (Botaurus melanotus), and the wild-duck Parena [sic] (Spatula rhynchotis).

Sea and water fowles
of all sorts are
however in no great
plenty, those known
in Europe are Ducks,
Shags, Gannets and
gulls all of which
were eat(?) by us
and found exceeding
good, ...

Author: FORSTER
Quote:
Ducks, shags, black
oyster-catchers, and
some sorts of
plovers were very
numerous here [at
Dusky Bay].

Author: BELL
Quote:
The Best kinds were
Ducks, Curlews, a
bird very much
resembling a Wood
Cock & Sea Pies; -
Shags, Wood Hens, &
Parrots were in
great abundance ...
the Wood Hen very
much resembles the
Common Barn door
Fowl in England

Author: PARKER
Quote: `There are eleven species of Native Ducks belonging to nine genera, all found elsewhere, except two--the little Flightless Duck of the Auckland Islands (genus Nesonetta) and the Blue Mountain Duck (Hymenolaemus). Among the most interesting of the non-endemic forms, are the Paradise Duck or Sheldrake (Casarca variegata), the Brown Duck (Anas chlorotis), the Shoveller or Spoonbill duck (Rhynchaspis variegata), and the Scaup or Black Teal (Fuligula Novae-Zealandiae).']

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
The hurling of
stones straight up
in the air so they
would fall into the
back-water with that
satisfying plup
known as a duck
fart.

Author: LELAND
Quote:
Duck itch: a RASH
that develops as a
result of contact
with a waterborne
parasite that
infests some of New
Zealand's southern
lakes. It has just
left its snail host
and is looking for a
duck to grow up in.
Look for warning
signs.

Author: MARSHALL
Quote:
`Used to be real
live-wires when we
were first married,'
said Mrs Foden
philosophically.
`Never missed a
tin-kettling or
first-footing;
euchre evenings,
sales, duck shoots,
dances, send-offs,
fires. We always
went. ...'

[Hdg] Blood on hands
of duck shovers.

The Government's
Proposals for
Resource Management
Law Reform: a True
Reform or a Case of
Duck Shoving?

They were fed up
with 'duck-shoving'.

No duck shufflin',
yer cow.

We have been the
perfect vehicle for
duck-shoving from
one department to
another. We have
been shunted from
the Health
Department to the
Social Welfare
Department to the
Education
Department. Each in
turn has declined
responsibility for
us.

Author: SHERWOOD
Quote:
The words flew, and
enriched Celia's [an
English visitor's]
vocabulary. `Duck
shoving' was the
local name for
buck-passing between
government
departments. A
`Queen Street
farmer' was a city
slicker who owned
land or stock for
tax-fiddle reasons.

The case was one of
a series of cases of
what was technically
known as `duck
shoving', a process
of getting
passengers which
operated unfairly
against the cabmen
who stayed on the
licensed stand and
obeyed the by-law.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote:
He absolutely
dropped his bundle,
and, to make matters
worse, I had started
off with a
duck'sbreakfast, but
I saw a cookhouse
and decided to give
it a pop for a
binder.
Notes: 1935 A.E. Strong WW1 scene in Partridge Slang Today 287

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote:
Duck's breakfast. A
drink of water with
nothing to eat: esp.
New Zealanders': C.
20. Cf. Irishman's
dinner.

... `ducks'
breakfast,' `to
float up to,' `to

Hotel' need no

Author: McGILL
Quote:
duck's breakfast or
dinner a drink of
water to WWI
soldiers.

I have been teased
for the way I stand
- it's called duck's
disease... Now that
I have left school
and I stand up for
myself and no-one
has anything to say
about duck's
disease, I am
getting on with my
life.

I have been teased
for the way I stand
- it's called duck's
disease... Now that
I have left school
and I stand up for
myself and on-one
has anything to say
about duck's
disease, I am
getting on with my
life.

I sounded Hirst &

impracticable
...[sic] Cutfield's
aid would scarcely

a duck's egg. The
whole affair put the
Ministry in a very
ungracefull
position.

The frilled shag is,
owing to its
cautious habits,
called the
`duck-scarer' by the

the above-mentioned
sound [Kenepuru].

It was a week or so
before the opening
of the duck-shooting
season.

The duckshooting
season started on
Saturday and all
over the country the
active hunters
stalked their prey
while the others sat
patiently in their
maimais.

Mr Dunne is strongly
critical of all the
national and local
politicians, roading
agencies and other
planning bodies "who
constantly dither,
duck shove and
otherwise
prevaricate" while
motorists continue

the notorious
Centennial Highway.

As the leader of the
[New Zealand]
Opposition
complained, the
Government has
`dodged and
duckshoved' the
issue.

duck-shove NZ &
Austral. sl..
Notes: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 149]

Quote:
duckshove to cheat
or pass

complaining of

Originally cabbies
jumping the queue in

cab ranks. ANZ.

And then there was
the bit where she
duck-shoved in
Parliament about
whether she had ever
seen, let alone

of apology.

Author: McARA
Quote:
Duckboards: Boards

When you get [the

Her pot and pan had

ducks and geese ...
police

ducks on the pond

[Keith Sinclair]

Fergus Staynes was

desire, in a world

Others wanted [to

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Duckstones and Tops
were the throwing

historical
importance. Others

and Drakes,
Snowballing, stone
and ball throwing.

At school, however,
there was little
place for Duck
Stones, with its
dangerous
stone-throwing.

Author: HEINZ
Quote:
Some of the simple
games played by the
[West Coast]
children were
rounders, shinty,
duckstone, tiggy
touchwood, kiss in
the ring, ...
cockfighting,
marbles, fly the
garter and leapfrog.
Notes: [c1870s] 1953 Patrick Magee (aged 86) Growing Up at the Diggings in 1974 Heinz Bright Fine Gold 38

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote: A game that was based directly upon children's interest in throwing stones was Duckstones (K-16). ... In the simplest form, the players put one stone on top of a larger stone and then attempted to knock the top one off by throwing other stones at it. The player who knocked off the most stones won. ... (South Clutha, 1875; Stillwater, Nelson, 1885; Wakefield, Nelson, 1875). Ibid. 167 In this [West Coast version of Duckstones] the duckstone belonged to the He. As soon as he put his duckstone on the big stone the game commenced and the others began to fire their own `dubs' at the duckstone.
(And) L. minor

Quote: (And) L. minor

duckweed [=] purple-backed duckweed: starwort: watermeal [s] ... duckweed, purple-backed [s] Spirodela oligorrhiza Kurz.

Some of that vitriol
came from Australian
fund managers who
got dudded in the
Lion Nathan deal,
but rarely invest in
New Zealand
companies anyway
because the playing
field is tilted in

The Pacifika concept

feeling that Cullen
Sports tried to dud
the Warriors and the
New Zealand Rugby
League and the fans

fast.

"Shoddy dropping"

Source: Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success
Quote:
Dudded: It is what
some absolutely
useless bastard does

Author: NEWBOLD
Quote:
Dud up. (v)
Fabricate evidence
to secure a
conviction

While presenting a
programme on Radio
Sport recently, I
asked listeners what
a "dudapper" was...
Eventually, one
caller came up with
the correct answer :
a dudapper was once
the term used to
describe a delivery
that bounced twice
before reaching the
batsman. Shortly
after, an elderly
gentleman rang in to
say that when he was
a youngster playing
school cricket in
England, a team-mate
by the name of
Nipper Dingle made a
specialty of such a
delivery. I
distinctly
remember," said the
caller, " our master
taking us for
practices and
saying, 'I've never
seen a boy who could
bowl a dudapper like
you, Nipper
Dingle.'"

Author: ROCHFORT
Quote:
We no sooner brought
up [at Lyttelton]
than ... our little
craft was crowded
with persons, eager
for news, smoking
their short dudees.

Author: MONEY
Quote:
... we were roused
by a roaring in our
ears, and had only
time, the one to
snatch his
pocket-book ..., the
other his black
dudheen ... before

furnace.

Source: Crusts: a settler's fare due south
Author: KENNAWAY
Quote:
[The Irishman]
smoked a short
dodeen pipe.

Author: SENIOR

[He] knocks the
ashes out of his
dudheen.

Author: A TRAMP

The boss of [the

Telling her he
hadn't seen such
lovely duds outside

tomother."

Author: KENNAWAY
Quote:
... our delicate ...
stomachs received

Quote:

This is Sunday, a

at our middle-day

The soil appears

The packer, who is
in charge of the

has had time to
build one.

A good 'duff' is

duff is terrible.

...

Jack was a wonderful

[station duff]

He was among the

...

Quote:
Another duffer of a
different kind took
place in July. Vague

Company and the New
Zealand Banking

Author: PFAFF
Quote:
I sunk a shaft on
the Larrikin's
Terrace there, but
it proved a duffer.

All hands.. are gone
or going to
theCreek.. which has
often been
pronounced"a
duffer". Here.. a
party got into
a"pot-hole" and had
got for two days'
worksixteen ounces
of gold.

New rushes are
spoken of every day,
and the township
which has sprung up
is full of life and
excitement caused by
the crowds of
diggers, packers,
and storekeepers,
all anxiously
awaiting the latest

Grey. Affairs will
not take their usual
course if we do not

back to the
Hokitika, loudly
declaring the whole

a "sell."

They turned out a
lot of "duffers".

I think I should
have preferred the
old claim at the
Thames, duffer as it
was.

The verdict of the
miners ... regarding

this, `that it is,

Author: MONEY
Quote: ... our claim proved a `duffer'. No less than fifteen shafts did we sink ..., but found a prospect of nothing sufficient to encourage us in working it. Ibid. 121 [Prospective diggers] had only arrived to find the whole thing what is called in digging parlance a `duffer' - i.e., that there was comparatively `nothing' to repay them for even the trouble of digging a single hole.

Author: WRIGHT
Quote:
He was working like
a nigger, sinking
duffers here and
there.

Author: VON HAAST
Quote:
This visit was
commemorated by
miners who took up
`Hochstetter' and
`Haast' claims,
which, as we have
seen, unlike their
namesakes, proved
`duffers'.

duffer 1. Useless or
stupid person. 2. In
Australia and New
Zealand, a
worked-out
orunprofitable mine.

Author: MAY
Quote:
DUFFER: applied to a
rush, a shaft, or a
claim generally. A
failure. Synonyms
were
`shicer',`stringer'
or, in the case of a
false rush,
`store-keepers'
rush'. A claim which
was exhausted was
said to be `duffered
out'. At Ross in
1866 putting down a
duffer shaft was
termed `sinking for
the Queen'. Duffers
(Creek) is a common
West Coast
place-name.

Author: HAY
Quote:
A duffer: No gold.
...CLAIMS Worthless
claims or ground
were called schicers
or duffers. Those
yielding up to
[pounds]3 per week
per man were known
as `tucker' claims;
up to [pounds]8 per
week were known as
`wages' claims;
above [pounds]8 were
known as `pilers';
the richest of all
were known as
`Home-ward-bounders.'

Author: NOLAN
Quote:
Duffer: a mine,
claim or gold-rush
which proves
worthless.

duffer ... 3.
Austral. sl. a. a
mine that proves
unproductive. b. a
person who steals
cattle.

... the place was
`rushed' by about
500 men, who
speedily deserted
it, and declared the
Waitahuna to be a
`duffer.'

Author: HOPEFUL
Quote:
If a man isn't `up
to the mark' he is
called `a regular
shicer!' This phrase
originated from the
gold diggings.
Supposing a man is
digging, but without
success, andhe
therefore abandons
his hole, it is
called a `shicer' -
that is, the ground
was called a
`shicer' or duffer,
thus the origin.

Source: Lay of the Old Identities, The
Author: BLAIR
Quote:
He puddled and
cradled, and digged
all he knew / When
the claim proved a
regular duffer.

It was soon found to
be a "duffer" rush.

Possibly the reason
why we have so many
duffer cows in our
herds is partly to
be found in our lack
of opportunity to
think.

The following tables
very well illustrate
the value of culling
out those cows that
the system of
testing reveals to
be "duffers."

It was necessary to
warn the
inexperienced buyer
who, guided by the
limitations of his
pocket, might secure
what on present
values, was a medium
or low-priced
animal, and finding
that he had bought a

Author: MAY

DUFFER: applied to a
rush, a shaft, or a
claim generally. A
failure. Synonyms
were `shicer',
`stringer' or, in
the case of a false
rush,
`store-keepers'
rush'. A claim which
was exhausted was
said to be `duffered
out'. At Ross in
1866 putting down a
duffer shaft was
termed `sinking for
the Queen'. Duffers
(Creek) is a common
West Coast
place-name.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH

Marbles had a

or `changers',
referring to the
marbles put down to
be fired at.

Author: GREEN
Quote: "Chris" Christoffells, the engineer at Rotorua, painted a typically English pub sign, The Dung Duster's Arms", and this hung in a prominent place behind the bar. Ibid 315 In the days when topdressing meant tiger moths many farmers were critical of how the fertiliser spread on the ground. They saw the superphosphate dust fall from the aircraft but it quickly settled on the grass and vanished from sight. A few pilots were astute enough to see the sprinkling of superphosphate on the cow dung in the paddocks. The farmers were called over to admire the dusting. So naturally topdressing pilots became "dung busters."

[Dun Mountain,

distinguished from
serpentine for which

taken, especially by
its greater
hardness, and its
crystalline
structure. I have
called it Dunite.

Author: HECTOR

mixture of chromic

chiefly associated

resembling olivine
in composition,
named Dunite by Dr.
Hochstetter.'

This mineral is a

olivine through

chromite are

specimen from the
Dun Mountain,
Nelson, was first

ed, p475) ...

Arty couldn't meet
our eyes as the car
pulled away. `What a
dunneybrush he
turned out to be,'
said Mathew [sic],
and we laughed.

Chatterton passed a
hand over his own
stiff, grey hair. A
dunny brush, he'd
heard it called.
Notes: (Marshall A Day With Yestermen)Also in 1989 Marshall Divided World 12

Quote:
Now, on to an even
more basic
subjectthan love or
jealousy: flies - or
dunnybudgies as a
friend with a
colourfulgrasp of
the language calls
them.

Author: SLIGO
Quote:
Their cavalcade
passed by, streaming
with pink dunny
paper ...

There is no shortage
of power, water,
dunny paper or
anything vital -
except rugby
tickets.

Most of us would be
hard-pressed to
think of a private
beach, aside from
the perennial topic
of dunny-paper
magnate John
Spencer's pile.

Author: HAWES
Quote: 'We're int6o dunny paper territory.'... Ibid. 17 'The dunny paper's stopped.'

Author: HULME
Quote:
... Joe tells her,
adding with a laugh
that Simon has the
luck of a proverbial
dunny rat.

Author: FRAME
Quote:
They had a nice
trellis-work too,
with dunny roses
growing up it.

Author: FRAME
Quote:
I drew aside the
curtains by `Dad's
seat' and looked out
along the path to
the cypress tree and
the old dunny with
its dunny roses
spilling in a mass
of white buds over
the corrugated
tin-hat roof.

Let alone the joy
when it's your go at
last and you can
"swing high as the
dunny roses"...

Dunny rose, /
Macrocarpa hedge, /
and the orchards /
where my girl-mother
/ picked apples /
through hot summers
/ have gone.

Author: FRAME
Quote: Along the path from the lean-to, the 'dunny' beside the cypress tree and soon known as 'the cypress', was covered with the small fragrant roses known to us as 'dunny roses', and was without a door, while the dunny seat, long and wide like a beach dunny, was set over a deep hole half-filled with old 'kiki' (our word for faeces) in varying shades of brown, topped with faded pieces of newspaper, the Oamaru Mail and the Otago Daily Times.

... its window
revealing a
red-painted
dunnyhouse under the
macrocarpas.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
He had worked out of
Christchurch ... he
said as he [120]
carefully rolled a
durry.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
durry cigarette,
usually
roll-your-own, the
making often called
durries, perhaps
associated with Bull
Durham brand
tobacco.

Author: MARRINER
Quote:
'Keep the durries; I
reckon you'll be
needing them more
than me.'

There was I,
watching King of the
Hill, blowing smoke
rings and feeling
lower than a snake's
belly on account of
recently falling
prey to the durry
again, and there on
the screen were Hank
and wide Peggy,
admonishing son
Bobby who'd just
been caught smoking
his first cigarette.

Simple rules for
survival: no pimping
(telling tales), no
stealing another's
durries (smokes), no
chatting up another
guy's girlfriend,
and no pooftahs.

His brother George
VI was a decent
enough stick who,
with the aid of a
strong wife (the
centenarian Queen
mother), and several
packs of durries a
day, got us safely
through World War 2.
"Got a durry?"

[I] am suddenly the
focus of attention
for three of the
little duskys who
are swimming
aroundand under
me... At one stage
we see a group of
four duskys mating.

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote: Nothofagus fusca Dusky beech

The inquisitive
dusky dolphins would
come to investigate
the divers and play
with them.

Without searching,
we were surrounded
by hundreds of dusky
dolphins.

The dusky dolphin (Lagenorhynchus obscurus) is perhaps as plentiful round the coast of New Zealand as the common porpoise. It can be distinguished from it by the falcate dorsal fin and the more pointed snout. It is black above and white below, with an oblique white band on the flanks.

Author: DOOGUE & MORELAND
Quote: DUSKY DOLPHIN ... Other names: Lagenorhynchus obscurus.

To the south and
further out are the
larger and more
acrobatic Dusky
dolphins.

Source: Excursion in the Northern Island of NZ
Author: COLENSO
Quote: Here ... the Dusky Plover (Charadrius obscurus) and the Southern Godwit ... were in large flocks. The natives call the former, Tuturuwaka [check ?-wata]. [1959 ed fn] Dusky Plover or New Zealand Dotterel ...
Notes: 1844 Colenso Excurs Northern Island in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 44

Quote: 61. Charadrius obscurus, Gml. Dusky, Red-breasted, or Mountain Plover, Big Dottrel [si], Tuturiwatu, Paturiwhata, Tituriwhatu-pukunui. - This excellent gamebird formerly bred on the Canterbury Plains ...; since farms and settlements have occupied the waste lands of the plains, for the most part it has retired to the mountains of the back country.

BIRDS' EGGS WANTED
.. Dusky Shearwater
...

Author: McARA
Quote:
Dust: Quartz dust
was a major menace
to the health of
miners. It blocked
up the microscopic
air-sacs in the
lungs, producing
hardening of the
tissues and
impairing the
function of the
lungs. Eventually,
sometimes after many
years, death
resulted. The
disease miners'
phthisis was
commonly called `the
dust.' It gradually
came to an end after
the indroduction of
axial-water-feed
drills.

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote: Dust `gunpowder'

The gold is in dust
and nuggets. ... The
implement most
effectual in
economising labour
is the `Long Tom',
or trough strainer,
cradles are but of
little comparative
service.

Author: SWAINSON
Quote: The dust consisted of flaky gold, of a pale lemon colour, largely intermixed with auriferous quartz, the separation having been effected only by washing in the simplest manner. Ibid. 109 These parties also brought up from the same spot various other specimens; one parcel of which, consisting of large rich dust and flakes, and exceedingly auriferous quartz (perhaps as rich, gaudy specimens as have yet been seen), was sold by auction by the undersigned yesterday.
Notes: 1852 Dec 13 Gold Circular in 1853 Swainson Auckland 106

Author: HYDE
Quote:
Hadn't so much as a
pick, he hadn't, and
when he came down
again he was
carrying his dust in
a sugar-sack on his
back.

The chief factor
influencing sales
and prices of
kauri-gum in recent
years has been the
rquest for the
poorer qualities,
called `chips' and
`dust'.

Author: STALLWORTHY
Quote:
At one time the
dust, and scrapings,
of the gum were not
saleable ... Since
then there has
always been a price
of some sort for all
dust and scrapings.

... it is no doubt
also responsible for
the dark coloured
varnishes produced
from the chip
grades. [fn] The
terms dust, seeds,
chips, nubs, &c.,
are the names given
to certain of the
lower kauri gum
grades according to
the relative sizes
of the pieces. From
`dust' the size of
the fragments
increases in the
order given, as does
also the purity of
the grade. Chalk, or
`chalky gum,' is a
particular grade
recovered from
swampy country and
is characterized by
its white or chalky
appearance and large
water content.

Author: McLINTOCK
Quote:
An increasing demand
for poorer grades of
gum [after 1900],
used in making
linoleum, made it
profitable to search
for smaller gum:
`nuts', `chips',
`seeds', and `dust'.

Author: REED
Quote:
The [1920 Kauri Gum
Industry] report
stated that during
the preceding few
years the proportion
of low-grade gum,
chips and dust
(scrapings) had
increased in volume
... to about
two-thirds of the
total gum exports.

Author: MALCOLM
Quote:
The scrapings [sc.
of gum] were kept
and sold as 'dust',
the bigger pieces
were known as 'nuts'
and the biggest as
'bold'.

In order of
decreasing size, the
pieces of gum were
known as nuggets,
nubs, peas, chips,
and dust.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
The greatest
occupational hazard
of mining was the
dust. ... Drilling
was all done dry in
those days. The air
was laden with
particles of flint
and quartz, ground
to the consistency
of flour. ... Once a
man was `dusted',
there was no cure.

Then they started
their series of
thefts. ...I notice
that there has been
a lot of `dusters'
working over there
recently, but these
men are the first we
have got of them.

Country Calendar
Bruce has been a
duster for years.

Author: LELAND
Quote:
Duster. When you
were a kid did your
teacher ever give
you the job of
taking the
BLACKBOARD ERASERS
outside and beating
them together
creating great
interesting clouds
of chalk dust?
Things are no
different in New
Zealand, except they
are called dusters.
This term is also
used for dustcloths.

As far as he was
concerned the
waterside workers
were less than the
dusties; they were
damaging the
country.

Ferocious dogs,
dangerous sliver of
glass ... are
obstacles faced
every day by men of
the Wellington
rubbish carts. But
anyone who thinks
these rubbish men
(or dustmen or
`dusties' as they're
sometimes called)
don't earn their
money, should spend
a morning with a
crew.

DUSTIES SEEK
SUPPORT. Wellington
City Council refuse
collectors are
petitioning the
public ...

Wellington dusties
returned to work
yesterday morning
after reaching
agreement with the
city council on a
dispute that stopped
rubbish collections
for two days.

`Excuse me,' Susan
broke in, `would
somebody mind
telling me what a
garbo is?' `Sorry
Susie. What they say
in Oz. A dustie,'
Nicholas explained.

I'd seen you all at
the pub I had taken
to frequenting, the
local Maori crim,
bus drivers',
dusties' pub.

No one told me that
the dusties
collectedthe rubbish
around the back.
Early. Andno one
told the dusties
that a whiterobed
flailer was not a
kehua, a ghost.

Dusties will stop
collecting rubbish
from the back door
of the house from 1
October.

[Hdg] Former dustie
switches to sales...
After a brief spell
studying mechanical
engineering at night
school, then driving
trucks.. [he] looked
round for something
more challenging.

Everyone left their
full cans at the
edge of the footpath
for the men we
called the
'dusties'.

Author: HALL
Quote:
The column moved on
through Barberspan
and Leeuwpan. [fn]
The New Zealanders
soon had good reason
to name this
unpleasant locality
`Dustpan.'

Source: Ernie and the Rest of Us
Author: BOSWELL
Quote:
He laughed when he
saw her gathering up
the pretty, furry
`dusty millers' as
they scurried across
the path and placing
them on Mother's
flowers ...
dusty miller [s] Senecio cineraria L.

[he] first met
"dusty millers", as
they were commonly
known, when he was
an apprentice in
Invercargill.

Source: In the Lee of the Hokonuis
Author: BARRY
Quote:
A `Dutch oven' has
been erected for the
purpose of burning
the saw-dust and
shavings, which are
drawn through pipes
by means of a
powerful suction
blast into the
furnace.
Notes: 1926 Prospectus of the Waitane Saw-milling and Afforestation Ltd in 1966 Barry In the Lee of the Hokonuis 147

Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author: BURTON
Quote:
A refinement of open
roasting was the
Dutch or camp oven,
a 38-centimetre
round iron pot with
legs and a handle so
that it could either
stand or hang.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
And in peace the
civilians must have
something to hate
too. The Dutchies or
the Pommies or the
Doolins or somebody.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
Mr. Jock Anderson,
..[116]. , arranged
to met [sic] a
new-Dutchman, ... As
he came onto a small
bluff he called out.
The Dutchie
responded ...

Many expressed
regret when the
`blasted Dutchman'
succeeded in
clearing his name.
The tendency to call
every foreigner `a
Dutchman' is well
known and amazing.

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
Take `Dutch Harry'
for instance. His
name was Henry
Wickson (or Wixon),
and it was said he
was an Austrian and
came from Memel. ...
To the whalers any
foreigner was Dutch
so that is how he
got his nickname.]

Author: EADDY
Quote:
Quite a number of
the trading scows
were manned wholly
with Scandinavians.
They were very
clannish, these
people, and should a
`Dutchman' as they
were always dubbed,
be appointed master
of any scow,
generally speaking,
that vessel would
eventually be manned
entirely by
`Dutchmen.'

[Caption] Among the
14 or so species of
reptile on Little
Barrier are
Duvaucel's gecko (at
up to 25 cm,
including the tail,
one of the largest
geckos in the
world), the very
rare chevron skink
(found only on
Little and Great
Barrier Islands),
and the Pacific
gecko...

Conservator Rob
McCallum said the
extermination of
rats would lead to a
dramatic return of
some wildlife,
including tuatara.
lizards, insects,
giant wet and
Duvaucel's gecko,
and a threatened
burrowing seabird,
the Cook's petrel.

Author: Jenny Jones
Quote:
Named after an early
French naturalist in
1836, Duvaucel's
gecko is a brown
gecko. It is the
largest New Zealand
species.

Indeed, rare species
such as Pycroft's
petrel, Duvaucel's
gecko and the New
Zealand native
cucumber are all
showing signs of
regaining their
foothold on these
islands.

Author: SALMOND
Quote:
dwang a short piece
of framing timber
fixed tightly
between studs, to
which lining
materials are fixed

In the night its
beams, joists and
dwangs emit loud
cracks.

The interior walls
of farm garages
revealjoists, braces
and dwangs in full
workingorder.

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote: Astelia linearis Dwarf astelia

The walls around us
bristle with
stalactites and
stalagmites. Some
are fragile, like
spun glass, others
solid Greek columns.
Sometimes they join
together to form
intricate
chandeliers,
curtains and "dwarf
beards" - waterfalls
of white rock frozen
in mid-air.

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote: (And) Cordyline pumilio. dwarf cabbage tree

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote: (And) Cordyline pumilio. dwarf cabbage tree
(And) Cordyline pumilio. dwarf cabbage tree

Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author: BURTON
Quote:
There is now little
doubt that the
primary migration to
New Zealand ...
brought the Maori
food plants from an
eastern Polynesian
homeland, ... These
plants were the
island yam
(Dioscorea
esculenta), the
bottle gourd, the
taro, a dwarf type
of cabbage tree and
the kumara.

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote: Mazus pumilio dwarf false musk

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote: (And). Sophora prostrata
dwarf kowhai [=] prostrate kowhai [s] Ibid. 42 kowhai, dwarf [=] prostrate kowhai [s]
The dwarf mistletoes also choose a range of hosts although Korthalsella salicornioides favours mainly kanuka and manuka.

Author: WILSON
Quote: Korthalsella salicornioides DWARF MISTLETOE ... Tiny green to yellow-green, jointed leafless parasite forming tufts or bunches on twigs of manuka.

Dwarf mistletoes are
found mostly on
coprosma, kanuka and
manuka. They often
go unnoticed because
they are so small,
but they are
distributed
throughout the
country.
dwarf montia [s] Montia verna Necker 50 montia, dwarf [s] Montia verna Necker

Author: TAYLOR
Quote: DWARF MONTIA (Montia fontana spp. chondrosperma). This European plant is widespread in New Zealand, and present in many pastures, ...

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote: The Dwarf-pine (Dacrydium laxifolium), which on the dry pumice soil has assumed the cushion-form.

Some reported being
frequently pulled
over by police for
no particular
reason, dubbed the
"DWB" or "driving
while black"
phenomenon, the
students found.

Capacity on the same
piece of port land
varies depending on
how high containers
are stacked and how
long each container
"dwells" or stays at
a port. It inceases
if containers are
stacked higher or if
dwell time is
shorter.

When Ms Elton joined
CentrePort the
average dwell time
(time on the wharf)
for a container was
15 days.

Author: PARTIDGE
Quote:
A burglar, esp. a
transient lodger
that pillages
boarding-houses:Australian:
since ca. 1910.
Baker 1945. Cf.
dancer, 6,of which
it is prob. an
elaboration - and an
alteration insense.

Particular
ensitivity surrounds
this case (the
second to be brought
within the first
month of the new
industrial relations
legislation) because
of the position of
the Distribution
Workers Federation
(DWF).

Speaking of Norman
Kirk, Bob Tizard
said "At times he
was perfectly lucid
[in Cabinet]; at
other times he would
wander off into a
fit of the
dwindles".

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote:
MIGNONETTE (Reseda
luteola) is called
wild mignonette,
scentless
mignonette, giant
mignonette and
dyer's weed. It is
not uncommon in
fields and waste
places in both
islands.
dyer's weed, [=] wild mignonette [s]

Author: SWAINSON
Quote:
In the detritus on
the sides of the
mountains, and in
the beds of the
stream, quartz
occurs in detached
blocks of various
sizes, mixed with
fragments of slate,
granite and trap;
but regulardykes of
quartz are not
generally met with,
although they are
reported to exist.

DYKE.- A wall-like
intrusion of igneous
rock into a fissure.

Near Carricktown,
however, several
dyke-like outcrops
were found, locally
known to the miners
as `dykes'. They are
not dykes, but
outcrops of hard,
bluish-grey, flinty
or horny quartz,
often much
slickensided on one
wall.

One vertical dyke of
solid whitish stone
of moderate
hardness, cuts the
line of the tunnel
at an oblique angle,
and I have seen some
indications of a
second intersecting
dyke.

Another feature
analogous to this
coal-field is, that
in this hill is a
dyke, apparently
descending
vertically through
the strata, of a
beautiful
conglomerate of
slate and quartz,
and which I have
never before seen at
this elevation.

Source: US War Dept. Short Guide to NZ
Quote:
A `john' means a
cop, not a toilet,
and the [38] latter
is sometimes called
(between men only) a
`dyke' or `house of
parliament'.

Author: HILLIARD
Quote:
But the dyke's in
the bathroom.

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Quote:
I have heard it
suggested that ...
the vulgar dyke for
`urinal' is used in
Ireland, ...

Author: HILLIARD
Quote:
Everything from a
light bulb to the
wringer to the
ball-cock in the
dyke.

Author: BAXTER
Quote:
The new guitar of
sex I kept on
twanging/ Inside the
iron virgin/ Of the
little smelly dyke,
...

They make you put
your head in a tuck
locker. Or go in the
Drying Room ... If
you stay on the dike
you can not [sic] be
tested.

A corrupt man can
sit on a dike and
watch [27] a tree
beginning to blossom
in the yard ...

Source: Avondale College Slang Words in Use
Quote: dyno: dynamite
Notes: Slang Words in Use (Goldie Brown Collection)
